I went from finding this game incredibly frustrating to appreciating the game for what it is. 
I'm a person who has a hard time seeing other's perspective.. 
And that's why I had a hard time with this game. 
I had such a hard time seeing other people's solutions so I had to look up how to do certain puzzles. 
But I have to say after 13 hours in the game that the more I play the better it got, I started thinking outside the box. 
I have now replayed the game 3 times and bought their dlc.  
My next goal is to 100% in this game.

Clean little organizational game. Most of the puzzles have fairly intuitive solutions, though I'll admit a few don't follow a linear path of logic. The placement of objects isn't too finicky and the sound work is very pleasant. I could probably play endless versions of the DLC.

This game is fun for relaxing by yourself. However, I turned this into a drinking game with my friends and it made it so much more fun. You need to play on 2 separate devices split into 2 teams. For every 3 stars that your team gets, the other team has to take a shot. It starts out really easy, but as you progress, not only do the levels get harder, but you also get drunker and thus thinking of solutions also becomes harder. 

[You can change the amount of stars needed to take a shot depending on how drunk y'all want to get]

I hate to be Procrustean about this, but it gets my thumbs-down because the controller support is more theoretical than practical. Due to my life-circumstances I can't comfortably play games that require an external mouse, so I depend on controllers unless the game can work with just keyboard buttons. More than a third of these puzzles were clearly designed with a mouse to gently nudge things this way or that; with a control stick this becomes an exercise in frustration. 

It probably is quite nice with the mouse, but I can't avail myself of that requirement.

Cute Game with great creative Puzzles. Also notable is the awesome score, which really makes the game relaxing and calming. AAnd especially notable are all the developer animals shown in the Credits. So overall a perfect Game.

I personally have 3 Problems, but those are completionist related. 1. The no Hint Achievement is placed further below the use a hint achievement. So because of this i used a hint on purpose to get the achievement and later deeply regret because i will need to wait some time till i can go through the game again without getting bored. I would just leave the: let it be achievement and use a hint achievement away, then a clean walkthrough would also be more interesting to achieve.
2. Having Achievements for the DLC is cool, but that they are placed in the main game again means: i have to buy the dlc to get 100%.
3. Having Dailys in a short puzzle Game is a big no go for me. I only Accept those in games where progress is basically optional like in Fortnite. If i dont care about the Battle Pass, i dont need to come back daily. At the same time those games are designed to be played forever, while this game is linear and when youre done youre done. Just as a completionist you have to come back daily to do those. Not a good decision imo.

Don't get me wrong, this game is well-made and probably deserves the hype. This rating is purely personal. I was excited to get this because I love tidying in real life (it was the drawers dlc that finally pushed me to buy and yes my drawers satisfy me) but for some reason, the process in-game would make me impatient/infuriated after just a few minutes. I love puzzles too, so it should've been an automatic recommendation, but I can count on one hand the puzzles here that gave me the expected seratonin after solving. 

Maybe it's that I'm a completionist and the miniscule adjustments needed (even when I get the gist of the solution) end up irritating me?? Idk, psychoanalyse away but something to consider for those with personalities like mine.  I will probably continue opening the game occasionally to solve one or two puzzles at a time, since that's apparently my emotional limit.

This is a fun little game.  I like that you can choose how easy it is (opting to skip levels and go back later, or choosing to reveal only part of a hint) and the art is very cute. It's a fairly quick game, but a number of the puzzles have multiple answers, so it's definitely worth replaying.

I adore this game! For the most part, anyways. I think that this game is a fantastic puzzle game when you just need a little bit of relaxation. Why worry about the tidiness of your life IRL when you can sit down and organize some batteries, rocks, and buttons into a cute little organized container! While that may sound sarcastic, I do think that this game is great for relaxation and when you just need to feel a little bit of satisfaction. There is just something incredibly rewarding about seeing all these odds and ends fitting together in exactly the right way that can put you in a pleasant mood. For the most part, I thought that this game did a really good job at providing unique puzzles that were all different in their own way. Further, while the story line was not overly apparent, there was an underlying theme to follow if you are paying attention. With the extensive puzzle list and the occasional "events" around holidays, you can get a pretty good amount of game play out of this game. Not to mention that several of the puzzles have multiple solutions if you just organize them in a different way. My biggest upset with this game surrounds the daily tidies and getting all of the badges for completing 100 of them. I found that there was really not a significant amount of variability when it came to the daily tidy, so it felt almost like pulling teeth to obtain that steam achievement and get all of the badges. I grew bored pretty quick of doing the same several puzzles over and over again in order to do it for 100 different days. I wish that there were more puzzles in the rotation so that it didn't feel like it grew stale and boring after a short period of time. The price of the game, I would say, is pretty decent. I might recommend grabbing it on sale rather than the full $15 price tag, but I also wasn't particularly angry at the price. All together with all the game achievements and to play through all the puzzles, I got a good 11 hours or so of game play. It was very easy to get all of the steam achievements, though some of them do require a decent amount of grinding, patience, and several days worth of your time. All and all, I would highly recommend picking up this game if you like puzzles, organization, and feeling satisfied!

TL/DR:
Fantastic game! The price point is pretty decent for the game play, but I would recommend getting it on sale. The DLCs also do help to extend your game play. The steam achievements are 100% manageable, but it does require at least a little bit of dedication and grinding for a few of them. The daily tidies are my biggest gripe, with them getting boring and repetitive very early on, making it annoying to get all the daily tidy badges for the achievement. It is fun, relaxing, and very satisfying. The puzzles are overall very unique, and the art style/animation is adorable.
Really fun! I love that certain levels have different ways of solving them and some really need you to think about what you're doing. It's great to just sit back and unwind.

A Little to the Left has some interesting concepts for puzzles, and playing through it is entertaining enough, but I think the puzzles could be explored and made better. 

The game has a bad flow, with slow switches between puzzle, menu and so on. Additionally the cutscenes are boring and un-skipable. 

I like the idea of the star system they use for multiple solutions, but immo more puzzles should have multiple solutions. 

I don't really like the hints for the levels. First of all, they don't help with multiple solutions (as far as I'm aware), and secondly, they don't explain why you are doing it. Showing a picture of what you are supposed to do is kinda boring, but I guess it's cool that you have to reveal it yourself.

Lastly the daily puzzles suck. Very repetetive, a bug/bad setup here or there, and just kinda boring. Also very easy to just work around the "daily" part of doing them. Just an unnecessary padding of extra content, to make the game seem bigger.

In the end it's not that bad tho. If you want an organising-game it's worth a play, if you are looking for a puzzle game, I'd say there are better picks.

[h1] A Little to the Left [/h1]is a very cute and relaxing game that tests your senses of spatial awareness and puzzle-solving abilities [b]simultaneously[/b]. It does this excellently by making earlier puzzles easier to build up your understanding of what the game is expecting you to learn. Each puzzle gives you very little instruction as to let you figure it out on your own, which makes solving each puzzle that much more rewarding. Each of the five chapters also focus on different subcategories of spatial puzzle-solving; such as, [spoiler]symmetry, categorical sorting, and overall spatial awareness[/spoiler]. I also think this is extremely well-done.

     One particular thing I really enjoy about this game is how simplistically enjoyable it is. From the [u]relaxing music[/u] to the [u]simple style graphics[/u]; I couldn't ask for more or for less from this game--the simplicity is the [b]perfect[/b] amount.

[h3]Simple Facts[/h3]

---> The game takes about [b]2-4 hours[/b] to play all the way through
---> The size of the game is [b]very small[/b]
---> As of writing this review, there is [b]one[/b] DLC that exists
---> Obtaining the achievement medal on this game means playing through the game a second time, and purchasing the DLC. There are also achievements that are very lengthy considering you must log on to the game to complete the "Daily Challenge" 100 different days

[h3]Problems or Cons[/h3]

     There is genuinely very little about which to complain about this game. The only problems I saw while playing it was on two separate occasions I was stuck on a level after having completely finished it; it wasn't advancing. This is kind of up in the air considering this could've easily been my fault, although it did seem like I had everything in place during those two levels. They were both apart of [b]Chapter 3[/b].

     Other than that, the only problem I have about this game is that there isn't any more. You can play this game in a quick [b]2-4 hours[/b] and I honestly wish there was more; however, there is the DLC which I am planning to play. Keep in mind I am not saying this game is too expensive for the amount of gameplay you get; I think the price is fair, especially considering this is an [b]indie game[/b].

[h3]Overall...[/h3]

     I think this is a wonderfully relaxing game to just sit back for a couple of hours and test your own brain. You can even grab a friend if you want to solve the puzzles alongside someone else. This game is everything right about simplistic puzzle games and I would give it a solid

[h1]9.5/10[/h1]

Mixed feelings on this game as a whole, mostly positive though. I think the core experience is really fun and worth getting the game for (maybe on a sale though, since I finished the main levels *super* quick). The DLC, should you choose to get it, is like another couple hours if you're just playing casually. For what it's worth, it was pretty fun. But then I went to achievement hunt, and this is where my review gets a bit more negative. There are two sets of achievements in this game that I'm not a huge fan of; daily login and locked behind the DLC.

For the daily login, you *can* cheese it by setting your system clock, but doing that 100 times in a row is tedious (trust me, this is how I did it). Additionally, the daily tidy system has very little variety as far as the types of minigames you can do. Overall, it just feels like a bit of a rushed system that you have to invest way too much time into because of the achievements.

The other achievements are locked behind the DLC. At least in some multiplayer games where they do this, you can at least still get the achievements by playing with people who have the DLC, but here you're kinda stuck. Pay up or have a bunch of missing achievements. For some people this isn't a huge deal, but for those who were looking to get this game to achievement hunt in, you will probably want to wait for a sale that bundles the main game and DLC together. Like I said, I had a lot of fun playing the base game, but since I try to only review games I've 100%ed, I figure I'd share my perspective doing so.

It's fun to have little sorting puzzles to organize household items in an aesthetically pleasing way. Some puzzles are more fun than others, and some are questionable how related they are to "tidying" (I'm looking at you, snowflake and constellation puzzles), but the main story doesn't take long to complete and is a creative and unique take on a puzzle game. If you don't care about achievements, you can stop reading here.

One thing I will say, is that if you care about getting 100% achievements, this game does not do achievements as well as it could have. In particular, the daily tidy achievements are very tedious. A few would be fine, but you have to complete 100 daily puzzles for the longest one (used to be 365), which playing every single day would take over 3 months to complete. And another one is to do 30 in a row, so if you happen to be on a trip or away from your computer for even 1 day in a month, you have to start over. These daily puzzles just cycle through a handful of the main puzzles too, so it never feels fresh.

Another issue is that even with just the base game, you can see the DLC achievements, which means getting 100% is impossible unless you purchase the DLC. I found that a bit unsatisfying for a game all about sorting items in a satisfying way, and more of a cash grab than anything. The last issue I would call out is that some achievements conflict with each other, such as "use a hint" and "complete the game without hints" - I didn't see both at first, so I just used a hint for fun to get the "use a hint" achievement, and now I have to reset my save and start from the beginning to get the other one.

Even with all that, I would still recommend this game. If you don't care about the achievements, or just go into it knowing that some will be tedious, the game is a lot of fun to play. It has great graphic design and was exactly what I was looking for in a puzzle game. But, if you're trying to 100% it like me, it can become more of a chore at times to get those last few achievements, which takes away from its strengths.

This is the best money I have ever spent, possibly ever. The art design? Impeccable. The sound design? INCREDIBLE, MY GOODNESS. The hit boxes and subtle things as small as the way the little X twirls when you close out of the settings? WOW. 

Some of the puzzles are very easy, some are incredibly creative, some are just satisfying as HELL and sometimes they're almost a bit TOO out of the box. The hint design is extremely clever to where you only have to uncover the parts you want, should you want to keep the rest of the puzzle answer unspoiled. The music is also just really nice.

I can't even begin to describe the joy I felt with how satisfying some of the organizing sections were. If you have autistic friends, I'm like 93% sure they will love you for the REST of their lives if you gift them this game. I was screensharing this game to mine and they practically came.

I have never wanted to support a studio more than this one and really look forward to their future work. the DLC is COMPLETELY worth it, this is the first time since playing Outer Wilds where I was 100% confident in my need for the DLC. 

The only thing I have to complain about is the cat, man's is cute but a SABOTEUR and a NUISANCE and a harbinger of CHAOS. And I do think its a bit of a cop-out for some of the DLC levels to literally just be petting the cat by clicking once. But I'll let this one slide, even if the pin-up poses he makes on the moon is kinda weird.

The achievement grind for this one sucks, specifically because of the daily achievements. Thank god for time travel, I was not going to play this game for 50 days straight. It is also a mildly infuriating game.

During the cold months my partner and I play video games together, but she finds many games frustrating. Most popular games pair keyboard and mouse controls with time-sensitive actions, which can be difficult for people who aren't chronically engaged in the hobby (like me :P).

There were also points where I had it correct, tried dozens of other solutions, caved and looked at the hint, only to realize I had it correct, but again, had something just slightly off. The worst case of this was the candle level.
That isn't to say the game is all bad, however. I enjoyed a lot of the solutions and the process in finding them. It's not a bad game, I just really don't recommend anyone pays $15 for it.

A relaxing cozy game. Perfect for procrastinating actually tidying up or just continuing if you already did so. It is obvious this was a labor of love game for the dev team.

The art style is minimalistic, the colors are pleasant to the eye and the music is relaxing. Perfect for a little breather from real life responsibilities.

The puzzles themselves aren't that hard to figure out, altho the alternative solutions aren't always the most obvious (the third solution for leaves took a while for me). The pacing they created with puzzles is amazing to me since I didn't know that was possible to do. I Love what they did at the end or rather with the puzzles at the end, it gave me a great feel good high.

While I do recommend this game for those who like puzzles and get a kick out of making things tidy, I must say I expected more content out of it. Its a solid 4 hour game (i did all the puzzles including the multiple solutions in this time frame) and for the price it's at i feel like it should have been more content to it, so i recommend getting it on sale if you are used to getting more than 4h of gameplay inside of this price range. 

That said it does have daily puzzles that are different everyday and work up to achievements that give it more replay value, since base puzzles stay the same.

A Little to the Left feels like is was made for me. As someone who habitually sorts their effects with purposeful direction, I found myself kicking my feet with glee upon sorting so many of the solutions in this puzzle game. It's hard to put into words, but this particular style of puzzle just makes my brain happy.
Fortunately, puzzles are not constrained to orthodox or practical sorting solutions. Instead, you frequently must perceive overarching patterns in minute details. For example, a series of objects may form a continuous pattern when arranged properly. When properly arranged, the solutions are so satisfying I had trouble tearing myself away from the game.
The puzzles strike a great balance of genuine headscratchers, and simpler yet still gratifying arrangements. A Little to the Left trusts you as a player, offering no tutorials or explanations for its puzzles. Inevitably, there will be the occasional alternate solution which leaves you stumped, and though rare, some of these are not altogether intuitive.
The game wraps up in a surprisingly sweet and arresting ending, and its feline "antagonist" is such a cute little fella. Then the DLC presents more involved puzzles which utilize the recurring patterns seen in the base game in larger spaces, often utilizing multiple patterns for different series of objects.
I adore A Little to the Left. No puzzle game has quite scratched the itch like this one, and I was joyous as I played through it. While its specific style is personally appealing, I also just think it's a tremendously charming puzzler all its own, and I encourage you to give it a try.

The game isn't bad, the art style was cute, and I did have fun with it. What frustrated me was that a lot of levels require a certain "correct" solution rather than...just organizing them as we liked, while still following the logic of the level. It felt really restricting unlike a lot of similar games which allow you to be more creative with your progression. 

Another disappointing thing were the achievements - there are some that need you to do a certain amount of dailies, as well as consecutive dailies. These are completely out of place in a game like this, where things get repetitive really quickly and considering it isn't a mobile game, which you can easily access on your phone for example. From what I read in the discussions, there used to be some achievements requiring even more daily and consecutive plays which were removed, but I still find the remaining ones to be pretty disrespectful to players' time. Good luck to the devs on future projects but I won't be 100%'ing this one.

If you've ever felt the inexplicable urge to rearrange your friend's bookshelf or straighten the crooked frames at your grandma's house, then "A Little to the Left" is the game you never knew you needed in your life. This charming puzzle game transforms the mundane task of tidying up into a delightful and addictive experience.

The game's premise is deceptively simple â€“ sort, stack, and organize items into visually satisfying arrangements. Each level presents a new delightful mess, from misaligned cupboards to arranging coin collections. The challenge lies in finding the perfect balance between precision and creativity. But beware! A mischievous cat lurks in the shadows, threatening to undo all your hard work with a well-timed paw swipe or a playful leap.

The graphics are as delightful as the gameplay itself, with vibrant colors and endearing character designs that bring the inanimate objects to life. The attention to detail is impeccable, making every pile of plates or scattered books a joy to behold. It's like Marie Kondo meets a Pixar movie â€“ heartwarming and visually appealing.

"A Little to the Left" boasts over 75 levels of satisfying messes, each more whimsical than the last. The increasing complexity keeps the game fresh and challenging, ensuring you never get bored of straightening up after these animated troublemakers.

What truly sets this game apart is its intuitive controls and user-friendly interface. The learning curve is gentle, making it accessible for players of all ages. Whether you're a seasoned puzzle enthusiast or a casual gamer looking for a relaxing way to unwind, "A Little to the Left" has something for everyone.

In conclusion, "A Little to the Left" is not just a game; it's a therapeutic journey into the world of organized chaos. With its playful concept, charming visuals, and intuitive gameplay, this puzzle game is a must-try for anyone who appreciates the joy of bringing order to the delightful disorder of animated household items. So, grab your virtual broom and get ready to sweep away the adorable chaos â€“ a little to the left, a little to the right, and you're sure to find the perfect arrangement!

If you're looking for a game to wind down with busy thoughts, 
this will calm you down and keep you relaxed with a puzzle game to end the day.
very fun

A few levels might be tricky, but there's a free hint, so you won't get stuck. It's both relaxing and challenging, which makes me want to play it more ^^

I will say tho the game does look aesthetically pleasing and the music is top notch, just not the type of difficulty I was expecting in a "casual" and "relaxing" game.

EDIT: After hitting the 30-day mark on Daily Tidys, I am significantly less enamored with this game. (1) Requiring a 30-day streak and 100-day total for the achievements is ludicrous. (And based on comments in the forums, it used to be WORSE.) I could see maybe, [i]MAYBE[/i], a 7- or 14-day streak and 30-day total. But [i]requiring[/i] players to play your game for over three [i]actual, real-world[/i] months' worth of days is massively hubristic. (2) Unlike in the base game, you don't get credit for a Daily Tidy unless you solve [i]every[/i] possible configuration. Again, this is ridiculous, particularly given that you need an unbroken 30-day streak. You should get credit for the day for solving one; and then each additional solve should count towards your total. (3) The puzzles are either increasingly tedious retreads or (e.g., as with the new Christmas puzzles) unnecessarily abstruse, mistaking obscurity for novelty.
[hr][/hr]
Particularly with the addition of the DLC, [i]A Little to the Left[/i] is a satisfying little puzzle game. I enjoy that quite a few puzzles have 2+ possible solutions, and I appreciate the "Daily Tidy" feature. Requiring a 30-day streak to 100% the achievements is a little wild, but them's the breaks. A few of the solutions can be a little abstruse, but that's the nature of puzzle games: it's basically impossible to design something that's going to give a reasonable level of challenge to a broad range of players while also never seeming unreasonable to everybody. Related to that, it's a great aspect of the design that you're not only allowed but encouraged (via achievements) to make use of both hints and the "Let It Be" mechanic. There's an in-game way to solve every puzzle; and also an in-game way that being stuck on a puzzle won't prevent you from progressing.

Somehow this game combines the challenge of a variety of puzzles (with little to no guidance on what's expected, in most cases) with the mindless pleasure of putting things in to order.  It really has struck a great balance between the two, which has made it really enjoyable to play.
A truly relaxing, cozy game for anyone who loves organization or has anxiety.

Calming and satisfying. I cannot overstate how great this game is. And it has a new mini level every day!

I felt like I was watching baby sensory videos partway through and the feeling only increased the longer I played.

Clips online that piqued my interest contained the most interesting levels, arranging woodworking tools using what appeared to be a random series of nails on the wall, organising a medicine cabinet where everything aligned perfectly... I had expected most of the puzzles to be as complex as these. Instead, it was mostly lining things up one after the other by size. Perhaps worthwhile for a young person (It feels rude to say child, but there you have it) as worthwhile edutainment, but not for someone seeking a challenging puzzle game.

It is beautiful, I will mention. The art is minimalist in an incredibly appealing way, but I feel the art is what misled me, in part, to believe the game was aimed at a 'mature' audience (for lack of a better term). Still, kudos when they are owed.

Would I recommend it? Well. It's a good tool to teach children logic, or for someone who just wants to move things around on a screen. And frankly, that's about it.

I feel bad not enjoying this one. I love these kinds of relaxing puzzle games. However, I found a few aspects tedious that were growing a little more obvious over time.

Some puzzles have more than one solution, but the hints are rigid. At least, I think so anyway, I did not see a way to get a hint for an alternative solution. So if you solve a more challenging puzzle but can't figure out the second or third solution, you're left either flailing or giving up. There were a few puzzles as well where I could see a potential solution, but it wasn't a solution that the devs had considered so it doesn't work.

But these were relatively small issues. The one that made me stop and put the game back was the soup can labels. The solution was obvious, yet it wasn't working. I finally gave up and checked the hint, and...I was right. I had been a pixel off of the exact positioning. It had multiple solutions, and I realized then that I probably would not be able to 100% this game. No hints for the alternative solution, and armed with the knowledge that it would have to be pixel-perfect I switched to the next puzzle. Solved it easily, but then found that some of the alternatives that I was coming up with weren't working.

It's not a good fit for me. Only some of the puzzles have a clever "aha" moment, and the game has a few intentional moments of making a mess. It might be a good fit for you, so I'd say give it a try and if it doesn't click after an hour, it isn't for you either.

Bought this game and its DLC on a whim after missing a good puzzle game in my life. (Namely, the Professor Layton games lol) And if you really enjoy puzzle games, you should definitely consider picking this one up.
In my opinion, this is a perfectly executed game. It knows exactly what it is, plays well, and the art in it is delightful. I have very little complaints other than just wanting more content. I can imagine how playing it on console might make controls a little bulky - but on PC it was perfect.

The music and sfx were also delightful, making the overall experience very satisfying and stress-free the whole time. I genuinely went to work and day dreamed about playing this game in the evening. It had a lighthearted feeling that I really needed right now.

I think for a very long time I discounted how lovely the sub-genre of "comfort gaming" can be in sake of a big dramatic narrative. And while I still love those games, this title really has left a lasting impression on me with just how calm it all felt.

It probably makes me an old lady at heart to enjoy this game THIS much, but thats alright : ]

Love this game! The basic content had a variety of ordering puzzles from super easy to medium difficulty, in which you have to pay attention to the details. The daily tidies continued to bring me back to the game every day, determined to get up to 100, but I wish there were even more of them. I really appreciated the newer DLC puzzles that were all medium difficulty but with more complexity. I hope they continue to add more of those levels. :)

If you want a game to fully relax and chill-out while enjoying the soundtrack, you came to the right place!

This game has simple-enough puzzles that will allow you to relax your brain from the world's stress. The achievements are pretty easy and there are online guides already that can help you out to complete them all in case you want to pursue that task. For the "daily challenges" achievements though, they can become really repetitive, so what I did was to modify my PC's date to the next days to make the challenges available and complete all of them in one gaming session, and I recommend the same since it can get a bit tedious to complete at some point, if you want to have all the achievements of course. But other than that, this is a great game in my particular opinion.

I originally played a friends copy on their switch. But I realized I needed to buy it myself just to write this review. This game is beyond incredible. The puzzle solutions are clever and extremely satisfying. My favorite solution is the Bread Clip or "Kwik Lok" Puzzle in Chapter Two, "Lost Recipe". [spoiler] The two obvious solutions, the ones you'd assume that the game is asking for, are sorting by height or by color, as there are 8 pieces, 7 of which share the colors of the rainbow. After trying to put things into place, the red piece, both the biggest and what would go first in the rainbow, locks into the center. That immediately makes the first two supposed solutions impossible. You then realize that the sides of the Bread Clips connect, which solves the puzzle! I personally think this is really well done since It wouldn't have been my first thought to connect them. Reason being, they look about the same as the ones you see on your bread. I believe the misdirect is on purpose, but who knows, maybe this was obvious to others! [/spoiler] But there's also so many other cool puzzles with amazing solutions.
The DLC is 100% worth it, the bundle is even on sale right now for only 3 dollars more!
If you like sorting/ organizing things then I definitely recommend this game.

I think that A Little to the Left is an incredibly charming puzzle game, between its sound direction, art style, and the mundane setting/puzzles focused on organization and grouping. It is a really good casual zen game. I have played both the original game and the DLC, which took probably around 6.5 hours. This and the DLC are both great plays, and as a bonus there is an archive of seasonal/holiday puzzles. For what you pay for in this game, you get a polished game with unique style and puzzles.

I have a few criticisms which do not change my enthusiastic recommendation of this game. As it is a puzzle game and each puzzle is highly memorable I have a harder time recapturing that initial experience where I am trying to solve something rather than remembering how to solve it, which diminishes the replay-ability for me. The controls/snapping into position can be a bit fiddly at times and I would occasionally go around the screen after completing a puzzle picking up and putting things down because one item was a few pixels out of place. I don't like the cat levels in the DLC where the puzzle is clicking the cat. There are too many of them and it inflates the level count without adding the challenge I want out of the game. I wish we could have the Daily Tidies that are new puzzles in an archive like the other holiday puzzles, untethered to achievements. When I want to play, I don't want to play for only one 5 minute puzzle.

The game is super cute. I love the simple design, limited color palette and overall cozy vive of it.

However, i I have to say, that this game can be so increadibly frustrating at times.
Not on purpose (or at least I hope it wasn't intentional), but accidentally. 

I understand that such games need to limit themselves to only 1-3 possible solutions for each puzzles, but the level designs can not only easily mislead, but also sometimes don't follow the pattern needed for the solution.
Examples I noticed not even 30 minutes into playing the game:

Level 7: books
Why the patterns on the books are so complex when they aren't needed for neither of two possible solutions?
Why the colors/color combinations of the books aren't simplified either? 
Those two things take all the focus and for no reason other than to frustrate the player. 
And yes, I know that it supposed to be one of the "points" of the game AKA for the puzzles to not be super easy, but.. No. Most if not all of the other ones are much simpler in the objects's design. Half of the patterns on the books don't even match the simplified aesthetic of the game. On top of that, since it's one of the first levels, it's goal shouldn't be to be confusing or misleading, since it serves the purpose of teaching the player how to play. 

Level 12: Calendar
There are two very similar in color and form kinds of stickers that surprise! don't have anything to do with each other... Why? Who knows, I certainly don't. But that's just a little side complain. The major is that- to my anger- the solution needed for this level don't FULLY FOLLOW THE PATTERN. One (1) single sticker is missing for it to be complete. For it to fully make sense.
Again, why it it's missing? Maybe for the pattern to not be "so obvious"? Well, the fact there're articles/sities with solutions for the game that litteraly say that the author doesn't even know why that's the solution clearly say that the solution isn't very obvious.

I love puzzle games in all forms (both digital and not) since I was a little kid. I played them for more than half my life, but I think that's the first one that made me rage quit out of frustration over details that could have been super easily avoided. 

I would really want to recommend this game, but I just can't.
The fact that those things are present in the beginning levels of the game makes me worry that they will be present also later on and maybe even in a bigger way. And since those kinds of games (especially with this aesthethic) mostly appeal to people wanting stress-free, cozy playthrough and younger teens/children (or their parents) I just worry that they might be disapointed just like (to some extend) I was.

I will definitely play it to the end since I already bought it and it's enjoyable for the most part, but I'm afraid it won't be a satisfying playthrough.

*Edit: ALSO! Another point why I don't and won't recommend it. The fact many puzzles are based only on colors or gradients and there's no option to make them more friendly to color-blind players is just baffling. It's a VERY easy fix and the game was long enough on the market that there's already a DLC published, so there's absolutely no reason why this accomodation isn't already present.

A Little to the Left is a spectacular game. I originally only saw it through YouTube shorts, and it looked very interesting at the time. In summary, A Little to the Left is an excellent game that has magnificent game art, with very relaxing/interesting puzzles, and a beautiful soundtrack.

I highly recommend this game to lovers of puzzles, satisfying organization, and/or cats. The game is challenging enough for an adult, as the puzzles may not always be solved exactly the way you think they will. I just bought the DLC and am excited to get started on that!

"A Little to the Left" caters to those who find joy in organizing items by patterns, but the experience isn't as straightforward as it seems.

- The game's multiple solutions for puzzles are intriguing, but finding the specific "correct" solution can be elusive. This becomes frustrating when a solution that visually appeals to you is not recognized as valid.
- Puzzle solutions involve various elements like object height, size, color, and symmetry. However, the object snap mechanism, crucial for determining correct placements, feels weak. Objects often need extra adjustments even when they are correctly placed, leading to confusion.
- The game's music was a letdown for me. It's repetitive and simplistic, with some tracks featuring high-pitched tones that were uncomfortable for my tinnitus.
- The narrative is minimal and underdeveloped, especially when compared to "Unpacking," which skillfully tells a story through item progression without any dialogue. A similar storytelling approach in "A Little to the Left" could have enhanced the gaming experience.
- I appreciated the flexible solution approach in "Unpacking," where the main rules are item placement in specific rooms and avoidance of clutter on the floor. Implementing a similar flexibility in "A Little to the Left" could reduce player frustration.
- In conclusion, while the game aims to provide a calming and satisfying experience, it often leads to frustration due to its strict solution criteria and missed opportunities in narrative and gameplay mechanics.

Speaking of hints, it's kinda disappointing that the hints are basically a wireframe version of the solution and not an actual "hint" like you'd expect.  That said, overall it's still worth a buy if you're into this kind of thing.

Review:
â­â­â­â­â­

A Little to the Left is a fantastic puzzle game for those who find joy in organizing chaos. The gameplay is simple yet satisfying, offering clever puzzles that appeal to both beginners and seasoned players. The minimalist design and soothing soundtrack create a calming atmosphere, perfect for winding down.

The only downside is its brevity â€“ the game leaves you wanting more. If you're looking for a quick and enjoyable puzzle game, A Little to the Left is a great choice
Definitely recommend to only play a chapter or two per day, as satisfying as it is, it does get repetitive. I also got it on sale since 15â‚¬ still feels quite a lot for such a simple game.

Nice game but let down by the short play time, considering the price. 
It's disappointing that several achievements are tied to consecutive dailies. Plays well on the Deck, but sometimes the controls are a little finicky using the touch screen.

Spent about 3 hours completing the base game. Very chill puzzles that doesn't wreck your brain too hard, with varying difficulty among the different levels, and very satisfying to solve. Love the amount of care that you can see and experience through the game especially through micro interactions (the cleared levels loading on the levels screen after you have completed a few was very satisfying to watch and listen to). Overall loved the game and might be getting the DLC soon :)

I love this game. I played it all the way through like 4 times, but there's a new puzzle every day. 10/10

Not only are many of the puzzle solutions entirely too specific/fidgety (to the point that even with a walkthrough I had to on multiple occasions play "hunt for the exact correct rotation/placement down to the pixel"), but many of the puzzle solutions require a color gradient as the solution.  As someone with mere color deficiency (not even color blindness) I found these almost impossible to solve without a walkthrough (and some even with).  The developers even noted this on their "list of things to address" with another review ages ago, yet it still is not implemented despite the game being on its first DLC.

What was billed as a relaxing and satisfying organization game became an experience in frustration and anger the further in to the game I got.  Can not recommend.

Everything is a little lack-luster, it's missing the replay factor, like... I got so bored after an hour. 
Also, not sure if it is my headphones, usually is - But never had to turn a game down in the settings so much.. Jeez. 

Also, when you go onto "levels" and you have to wait for the animation to ping that you have done each one... That should be skipable. 

Honestly, people might enjoy it... It just isn't my cup of tea.

Pros:

- Fluffy kitty! Precious, fluffy kitty!

- Fun

- Usually relaxing. Only a few puzzles are stressful (stressful for me anyway), the ones with the symmetrical plant leaves.

- Music is good. I love the chapter 1 song and the ending song!

- The ending is beautiful! I love it!

- Nothing inappropriate. People of any age can play

- I like the achievements and dailies too

Cons:

- Not enough precious, fluffy kitty

- The symmetrical puzzles

- Puzzles that are too easy. It's not only wasted puzzle levels, but it makes it so my favorite music on chapter 1 isn't listened to as long because chapter 1 is easiest and finishes faster than the others! But I guess that's just what happens when my favorite music is on chapter 1.

I truly love this game.  It fulfills that need I have to organize, to solve puzzles, and to see pictures of cats.  The art is truly lovely, the game plays smoothly, and, while some of the puzzles are easy, some really take thought -- or even a hint -- which makes for excellent gameplay.  I played over an hour straight on my first session, and had a smile on my face the whole time.  Some levels did prove frustrating later on, but most of my time was sincere pleasure.  It took just over ten hours to complete all the solutions for each level of the main game and the DLC.  It's such a great game for me, though, that I reset the levels and am playing again.  Highly recommend if you get satisfaction from symmetry, perfectly placed items, and finding order in chaos.

First: The design is aesthetically cozy and fun and there's something gratifying about "tidying up" the puzzles. 

I played a few levels and felt like the game was a little flat. The same type of game (rainbow/size/number order... over and over). About the time I was ready to quit because I was bored, the game design added some "arrange these objects into the right size containers" games... they were a little more engaging and I was excited that the game was leveling up. I kept playing because I felt like it was gonna get good soon.

Unfortunately, it never really went anywhere after that. I wanted some puzzles that were challenging. There were some that were frustrating, but because of what seemed like poor design, not intellectual demand. All I got were more of the same kind of puzzles. Over and over. 

The end was lots of (beautiful and fun) animations that I wanted to click through and get to the next stage, but couldn't. Then it was over. Overall, the game had fun moments but I played through the whole thing in about 3 hours of actual gameplay while watching TV and for me, it never got to truly gratifying puzzles. Was cozy and fun, but not challenging or particularly engaging.

I would give it a 2/5 because I kind of feel like I wasted an evening wishing it was something else. But I think it depends on what you're looking for. If simple, relaxing cozy puzzle games with great illustrations are your vibe, this is for you! I see the appeal, it just wasn't for me.

If you're like me, you've heard nothing but good things about A Little to The Left, and that is for a reason! 

The art design is stunningly adorable, beautiful, and polished, the sound design is nothing short of a chef's kiss, and you can tell that at every turn the creators put so much thought and effort into every little detail. The puzzles range from simplistic to challenging and this is furthered by having multiple solutions to various puzzles! It helps you to think inside of the box, outside of the box, and all around! Every time you figure out the solution there is a euphoric feeling of accomplishment (and perhaps a bit of embarrassment from learning you were overthinking the entire thing)!

The replay ability is incredible as well. Not only are you able to go through and play the entire game (and DLC) after just a little time away, but you can also play specific puzzles that particularly piqued your fancy. There is also the addition of "Daily Tidy's" which will keep you coming back day after day! 

This is hands down my favorite comfort game and I genuinely thank the creators from the bottom of my heart.

Beautiful game with a great vibe. Gorgeous animation and great music on top of the fun and relaxing game play. I'm not one for games with a ton of narrative but it can get a bit boring sometimes so i really enjoyed the edition of the cat throughout! super cute and humorous. I got pretty stumped a couple times but overall a super satisfying and calming game! The final level is wonderful! Winter is coming and I've been bummed about it, but I put fire ambience on my TV and curled up with this game- poof! gray and cold day turned to a cozy and relaxing evening. Highly recommend!

Also I'd be nice to do more than one, as it mostly only takes a minute to solve them. A selection of 3-5 daily puzzles would be great,

Fun, challenging and satisfying game. I really can't get enough of it, and I'm sure my friends are tired of hearing me talk about it. The overall design is very charming, with an analog vibe and a pleasing color palette. The gameplay is seamless, especially since they added the replay option on the puzzle end screen. It's nice to be able to immediately replay a level for the puzzles with multiple solutions without having to exit and scroll back to it through the menu. I love the concept of the Daily Tidy, and it's always fun to have a new puzzle to play every day. Because the puzzle formats are (understandably) repeated in the Daily Tidy, sometimes it can be a bummer to get a repeat Tidy that has an easy solution when I'm in the mood for a challenge. Looking forward to any and all future expansion packs!

I feel like this game was made for me. It is incredibly satisfying. I keep playing it over and over, and even though I know all the solutions it's still making me happy as each object snaps into place. The DLC levels are delightful. So relaxing. Even my non-gamer family enjoys it.

Edit: It's been 100 days of taking little moments to relax with A Little to the Left. I still love it just as much as I did the first day.

If we ignore the Daily Tidy achievements, which are the epitome of worthless padding just to grind out a number (100 days of the same 10-12 puzzles? Really?), this is one of the best games I've played in a while.

The simplicity in its presentation, music, and art style bring about a super charming experience that was a load of fun to go through, and only about 5 or so puzzles were total duds, the rest were really satisfying to solve.

Go into this one as blind as possible!

A very cute and relaxing puzzle game. The music is really calming, I could listen to it on repeat completely independent of the game. The puzzles themselves are very visually appealing, and present enough of a challenge without being TOO MUCH of a challenge, you know? 

I also love that there are multiple ways to do several of the puzzles instead of it being one and done, there's so much creativity put into the solutions. At first I was a bit disappointed that the Daily Tidies are repeats of puzzles you have done, I thought they would be new puzzles introduced daily but tbh I understand how unrealistic that was. I still enjoy doing them for the achievements, and it's definitely helping me to get in the practice for the perfection achievement hehe.

This is such a satisfying game. It is cute, cozy, and has a good soundtrack. It is visually appealing and the level breakdown makes it easy to play for a short or long sitting. Did I expect to get emotional when beating the final puzzle level? No, but call backs to previous puzzles, motivational music, and a familiar friend all came together to make me tear up. A simple, thoughtful game that builds on what you've learned earlier. Sometimes challenging, but never so much that you quit and want to never come back. Eagerly awaiting more DLC, this was well worth the inexpensive investment.

I sincerely think it's not fair that you've added demanded daily play achievements for 100% completion. Can't recommend it for that reason alone, even if the game itself is short and sweet.

EDIT: It appears that a developer has responded to this review. 

Please do understand that while I did enjoy my time with this game, I cannot support daily grind achievements. While there ARE many people who enjoy daily tidies, there are people who DON'T at the same time. By adding these, you're locking several players out of 100% completion.

What if somebody isn't able to get to their computer one day? A 30 day grind achievement is REQUIRED for 100% completion, and if somebody misses a single day? Boom. Done.

I'm sorry, but I still do not think these should be in the game. By rewarding fans of the tidies, you have accidentally created a situation where you've locked several people out of a complete experience. My genuine suggestion is to at least remove the DAILY ones. The 7, 14, 30 ones. These lock a HUGE majority of individuals out of the achievements at hand.

Please do keep in mind, I am a fan of what is here, and I would legitimately love to give this game a positive review for the gentle puzzles and serene atmosphere. But I'm sorry, I just do not think it's justifiable or correct to have these achievements on hand.

I found the DLC to be more fun than the actual game. The game itself is very calming and keeps you occupied with fun puzzles which I enjoyed, however the price is way too high for this kind of game. The game itself can be finished in a couple of hours and then there really isn't anything else to do. The replay value of the game is low as it is just puzzles you solve once (or twice if you want to get all the solutions). I definitely recommend getting it on sale if you're planning to buy it, but overall the design and music of the game is great and it is a cute idea. In my opinion, there should have been way more levels and more to do in the game besides the daily tide. Some of the levels are also not puzzles at all and just require you to click a few times on the screen which was disappointing. The organizing levels with the cupboards and drawers from the dlc were by far the best and there should have been way more of them. Was quite disappointed in how quickly I finished the dlc (within an hour).

I absolutely love this game. The puzzles are uniquely entertaining, the solutions to so many of them are perfectly complex, but you always have the option to get a hint or 'let it be' if something is a little bit too frustrating. The daily tidy keeps you coming back, and the new archive levels are a blast. Their player support is incredible, they get back to you so quickly and seem glad to help out to ensure that their players are enjoying the game. If you're looking for something to help you let go of the stress of the day, this game is absolutely the way to go. Thank y'all for making such a great game!

Cute, simple puzzle game. I 100%'d the main game in about 3 hours. Some puzzles are immediately obvious, while others will have you frantically moving pieces around for 5 to 10 minutes. It's mostly simple pattern recognition and organization, if you enjoyed Unboxing or Assemble with Care, you'd enjoy this. The game introduces some new physics-based mechanics in Act 4 but immediately returned to patterns, which I was disappointed by.

Don't buy this game for challenging puzzles, buy it for a few hours of cute, cozy, simple gameplay.

After playing A Little to the Left for 100 days straight, I can honestly say that it's a really peaceful way to do daily brain puzzles (often with more than one way to organize or solve a puzzle) with a subtle puzzle storyline that incorporates the messy chaos of living with a cat. It's a gorgeous game of puzzle and organization that anyone who likes games similar to Assemble with Care and Unpacking will love. 6/10

Cupboards and Drawers DLC: The new DLC adds 25 new levels with some interesting new mechanics of how to organize and is a great expansion for anyone who enjoyed the base game. It's another cute addition with little breaks for reprieve about ever 5 levels or so that involve petting the cat (which makes it more than worth my money). 5.5/10

Snack Pack, Something Eggstra, and Good Tidyings: This archive collection brings a lot of seasonal joy to the game. Hopefully they add back in the achievements related to these tasks to encourage more people to explore cleaning this clutter. 5.5/10

This game provided me with one of the most incredibly profound experiences I've ever had when playing a game. It is like I could physically feel the love and soul poured into this game from the developers and artists and it just overwhelmed me at the end once I finished all the levels. The way the cat character's narrative developed through the progression of the game was so beautifully subtle, and if you have a pet you love I feel the impact of this narrative wont be lost on you. Even in the designs of the levels, some of the items you are tidying up feel like they belong to someone, and the act of sorting out their items feels like an intimate connection with someone very unique and special. The game is very short and I would recommend playing through the whole thing in one sitting to get the whole experience. This game has mountain loads of creativity with such a simple and effective concept coupled with beautiful art, music and sound design, I can't see how you could regret picking up this game. And thank you Max Inferno for an experience I wont forget.

A Little to the Left is a super comfy puzzle game that often presents you with a rather simple but disorganised scene which needs arranging in a certain way. These puzzles range from sorting items into compartments, arranging stacks of boxes or finding hidden patterns in everyday objects.

The puzzles are of a very nice difficulty, never going too far off of the deep end, although I would argue that a few can be a bit unclear as to what the end goal ultimately is. Still, a handful of the puzzles you encounter have multiple solutions, which it encourages you to explore and find all of. I personally found this to be quite enjoyable as often I would find one solution, and come back later to explore it with a different mind and find the other solutions.

The game also has some sort of daily new puzzle system which appears to make variants of existing puzzles in the game, leading to a nice treat should you wish to check in each day for a few minutes of thinking.

I'd recommend this for anyone looking for a very light and relaxing puzzle game. Bonus recommend if you're a cat lover as you'll often find your progress charmfully impeded by a feline friend.

A Little to the Left is leaning in general towards a good game though it has some very vexing things in it as well, it becomes especially apparent regarding Steam Achievements.

so the BAD first :
like eg the Daily Tidies have a very small number of puzzles but since those are tied to multiple achievements, so you have to do lots of them & then it becomes rather a chore since they repeat very often & if you on top dislike one of the puzzles, then you will have a bad time while playing.
another annoyance is the paid DLC tied to a set of the base game's steam achievements, so before you buy be aware that if you don't buy the DLC as well, your achievements will remain incomplete.

the MIXED second :
in general i find actually the price a bit steep for what the game has to offer, since the replayability value is very low. the graphics are lovely & well made, navigation is overall pretty smooth though at times a bit clicky & confusing but it's nothing gamebreaking. the music can be jarring at times when you sit on a puzzle for a longer time & the music is repeating in a very small loop of the same sounds over & over & over again. at least you can mute the music separate to the other sounds.

the GOOD last :
so what's the good aside of the design & general nifty idea ?
it's a unique game with a very consistent idea & not striving to be something else. many of the puzzles are also NOT forcing you to do it the preprogrammed way but the game accepts YOUR solution, YOUR placement, YOUR sequence, which offers at least a bit of replayability since you can try other placements later on.
the game has also a good variety of puzzles & doesn't remain in the same pattern. on top, should you have extreme difficulty with a puzzle you can always use the in game Hint or if even that isn't enough, the nice community provided solutions as Guides.
the game is also pretty humourous & a bit cheeky, which gives a relaxing vibe not to take tidying up too seriously.
i am not sure if i should mention the addition of CATS under the label of "good" but maybe you are a cat lover, so you will be pleased to know there are some innovative cats inclusions in the game ^^

i hope the devs stay on course, improve the Daily Tidies with time by adding all of the game's puzzles into it. & maybe also with time there will be more DLCs at a bit lower price, cause the length to price ratio is a bit steep imo.

if tidying up & straighten fills you with satisfaction & if you have fun organizing things along different patterns & methods or if you just want to take a peak into the realm of compulsive organizers A Little to the Left is your chance.

A very relaxing and peaceful game, with nice music. It can be very slow paced or quick paced; depending on the player and how they wish to play. It has a nice interface and overall is an enjoyable experience.

if you are more into organising things by shape, colour or order, the DLC is a really nice bonus to have, as the base game has all sorts of puzzles other than organising such as symmetry puzzles. (although these are sometimes confusing)

I quite like the fact the game doesn't 'punish' players for not understanding the puzzles so you can have unlimited hints which don't affect scores. But also the game encourages players to find multiple solutions to certain puzzles so you can't be wrong on these specific puzzles.

Overall, I'd give the game a 10/10, despite some of the bugs I've encountered that sometimes make puzzles impossible to complete (restarting the game fixes these bugs), it's not infuriating or annoying to get these bugs due to the calm atmosphere of the game. :)

This game was a great start with cozy and relaxing puzzles. As the game continues on, puzzles become more difficult to a point of it seemingly not making any sense or indications of how the puzzle needs to be solved. Nothing is explained on HOW a player is to discern if they have the correct answer other than a bell indicator which gets lost in the music which also has bells in it. When a player gets too frustrated and needs help, the hint menu either literally gives you the answer OR has nothing to do with the actual puzzle. There is no middle ground of nudging you in the right direction to solve. Through the power of the internet I was told that the star rating system after you solve a puzzle is based on HOW you found the solution, rather than how fast/accurate you came to the answer. The games never indicates that a puzzle can be solved in more than one way. The lack of direction, indications, and confirmations makes this game not enjoyable [for me].

If you would enjoy a puzzle with absolutely no hand holding until you want a "hint", this game may be for you.

leaving a positive review because it's genuinely a very good game, but personally, i would not recommend it to anyone, unless they seriously enjoy arranging things that borderline on OCD.

this game was actually rather stressful at times, as when i thought i had finished the puzzle, the game demanded i went into OCD mode to complete the level. such as, items being in a perfect exact order, even though on other levels it didn't matter, to the point where i felt it was more a chore to complete the level, than satisfying. 

and yes i understand the difference between neat & tidy vs OCD.

the DLC was a lot shorter than i thought it was going to be, personally i feel it should of been 2x as long as the amount of levels that were in it, making my purchase worth it.

i do like the free daily puzzle, but i don't see myself coming back to the game everyday to play it, now that i have completed all the puzzles in all the multiple ways to gather all the achievements. 

also the game promises to see the cat quite often, but i barely saw the cat throughout the game, only popping up at a few seconds, or replacing a slot of a puzzle in the dlc, where i literally just move my mouse over the cat. (quite lazy tbh, i guess others would find it a cute feature). but overall, i want to tick i do not recommend, but as i do not want to leave a negative review, i will just air out my complaints in this positive one instead. 6/10.

I'm not a huge fan of this. It's cute and cozy, and the idea of tidying up household things is sweet, but not one of the puzzles have felt remotely intuitive to me. I frequently get frustrated and look at the hint, and not one time have I said "oh, that makes sense." It seems random, the solutions to me. If it's on sale, it's not too bad, but I rarely play

[b]Hold on, this is going to bother me all day if I don't organize my papers.[/b]

Ah tidying and organizing things. I loved tidying and organizing things as a kid and I still do now. Stacking papers (or paper-like things) in order from biggest to smallest, organizing books in various different ways (while keeping a book series together), organizing drawers and making sure all the measuring cups/spoons are together, organizing things by color, and oh boy the maddening task of trying to get a frame perfectly straight on a wall. On one hand itâ€™s going to bother you for a while (and whenever you notice it again), but on another youâ€™ll forget about it eventually and not sweat about it as much. Not to mention some annoyances like where do I put multi/duochrome polishes or when you have a whole book series in paperbackâ€¦except one that was only available in hardcover (and is thus taller than the paperbacks). Anyway, the point is, when I saw A Little to the Left it felt like a game I had to check out eventually. I like tidying things up and this game is about tidying things up. Win win.

A Little to the Left, as you probably expect, forgoes a story to purely be about the tidying up puzzles. Though, it does seem like a lot of these were caused by your cat who seems to love messing up your meticulously tidied places and do the classic â€œknocking things off the tableâ€ cat move. The game is separated into five chapters where about 80-ish puzzles are organized in based on whatever theme they fall into.

A Little to the Left is pretty simple, but there are a lot of puzzle variations as well as objects that youâ€™ll be interacting with. The tidying and organizing itself starts out pretty simple and does build up in complexity a bit (just a bit, it never gets too complex). At first, as well as sprinkled in throughout, we get super simple levels like straightening frames and meticulously placing everything in their place on a desk; but it builds as you soon find yourself organizing books, a kitchen drawer, and boxes. Making sure everything is in their right place and is in the right order. Aside from trying to figure out the solution, all you need to do is drag the items around to the right place (or in certain levels click or pluck). Your cat also makes an appearance every once in a while to playfully swipe at your work.

Itâ€™s important, though, to remember that a lot of levels keep symmetry in mind. There are purely levels where you have to make things symmetrical (in the last half of the game though), but if thereâ€™s items in a level that are symmetrical, share color schemes or could be made into a color gradient, or even items that together make a design or are alternating directions itâ€™ll call for you to have it symmetrical. Sometimes itâ€™s easy to forget, or not know early on, but most of the time the level isnâ€™t completed thatâ€™s why.

Honestly, I think my favorite levels were those that I actually do in real life like organizing books and drawers. And I think those are the levels the game does best since there are a few levels that I didnâ€™t feel really fit (which all show up in the last chapter).

There is a hint system here in the form of a scribbled out notebook. All you have to do is erase the scribbles to see the hint. Although, itâ€™s less of a hint and more giving you the solution, or the main solution for those with multiple solutions. I actually didnâ€™t look at hints apart from maybe an handful, though it was useless for multi-solution levels since the hint usually is a solution you already figured out (aka the easiest solution). So I wouldnâ€™t use hints unless you want a solution (and especially if you want the achievement where you donâ€™t look at the hints). Thereâ€™s also a â€œLet it Beâ€ option which serves as a skip so you donâ€™t have to be stuck if youâ€™re someone that doesnâ€™t want to look up the solutions.

Though, there were some personal disappointments and annoyances for me. There were a couple of levels that I didnâ€™t like, which turned out to be a level where you arrange a stack of boxes (that one was so annoying) and the plant symmetry level where youâ€™re plucking leaves (and if you pluck the wrong one all leaves regrow). At first, the levels where you create a symmetrical pattern with objects was one that annoyed me too, mainly since I got one as a daily tidy before I got to it in the main game and was doing every other possible solution, but it grew on me as I was doing the daily tidies. I did also think some were a bit too obtuse or a specific part of a level was a bit too specific (or even one where it has the crumbs be part of the solution rather than throwing it away like before). There were some that didnâ€™t quite make sense until I saw the solution. Not to mention the last level going on for a bit too long.

I did expect there to be more levels with multiple solutions as well, and it didnâ€™t help that there were some one-solution levels that I found other solutions for. Like the egg carton one, which I tried organizing it like I usually do rather than what the game wanted.

I also did wish levels with multiple solutions gave you a choice on replaying rather than automatically going to the next level like usual (when youâ€™re playing through the first time). Or having it as a setting. I, personally, liked getting all the possible solutions at the same time rather than going back later and it was a bit annoying having to exit out to select the level again.

I did hear the cat annoyed a lot of people, but for me the cat didnâ€™t annoy me. Maybe itâ€™s because the cat was silently toned down a bit before I bought A Little to the Left, or maybe I was doing the levels the cat can mess up too quickly, or maybe itâ€™s because I had a cat before for years as a kid; either way Iâ€™d say donâ€™t let this aspect turn you away specifically. I honestly was expecting the cat to have more of a presence as it did, but it just made the occasional appearances and I did find it easy to fix up what it did mess up anyway.

While the main game will only last for a limited time, there is a bit of the game that asks you to return to the game every day. A Little to the Left has a â€œDaily Tidyâ€ section of the main menu, which everyday will give you a quick tidy puzzle for you to do before it resets at midnight. Daily Tidy takes a handful of levels and remixes objects or patterns to try to keep it fresh. For the most part itâ€™s okay, but I didnâ€™t like the constellations or the plant symmetry tidies. Though, this is where I came to love the symmetrical pattern ones. Luckily, you can just change your systemâ€™s time if you donâ€™t want to wait. Or you want to play the Christmas and Easter Daily Tidies without waiting (and honestly, I think the Christmas ones were my favorites).

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
For the most part, I did like A Little to the Left. Like I said in the beginning, I like tidying and organizing things in real life so a game where you do that felt like it was made for me. While it did fall short in some aspects, I did still like playing through all the levels and couldnâ€™t keep myself on a â€œone chapter per dayâ€ plan. Itâ€™s good and if this is the type of thing you do in your life, or this puzzle type appeals to you, I do recommend it. 

Though, I would wait until it goes on sale. I got the game for around $11 and had a little bit under 7 hours, after completing the game and getting all but nine daily tidy achievements, and I felt it was worth it. And even better, since there is DLC and a bundle, if the main game is discounted you can get the bundle for a bit over the price of just the main game when itâ€™s not discounted.

my girlfriend saw this game on social media and really wanted to try it because reviews were giving it good reviews and also saying it was a very relaxing game as during the time she was stressing about a lot, after watching her from 1% to 100% and buying the DLC i can say it was worth the price and the simplicity of this game along with everything else the game has to show. Relaxing game with beautiful artwork and good puzzle design. Reminds me of my cats Georgie and Till, who passed away 2 years ago and a year ago. This game will forever stay in my heart and in my Steam library for those stressful, exhausting, or bad days.

It is a very cute and surprisingly challenging game. With no instructions, some levels are surprisingly difficult and require quite a bit of time to solve. I was worried that this game was going to be too short. I really loved the organization levels, and I am very glad that I bought the DLC because I really LOVE everything about the DLC!
I wish the game was a little bit longer, but I look forward to seeing what these developers do with this game in the future! :)

Very enjoyable for people who like sorting objects like myself. I previously stated that this game was not worth the full price as it went by too fast- I have since played almost 30 hours of this game and have not stopped enjoying it for even a moment. For a period of time, I was immensely depressed and was unable to do any of my hobbies- including video games- due to a loss of interest. This game kept me from completely losing interest as a whole and made me feel better when I felt like my life had no meaning. Like, it is literally just a game, but it really did help me get back on my feet.

Additionally, my save file was bugged for a while and I corresponded with the Max Inferno team and they put so much time and care into helping me out and solved the issue in about a week. Amazing team of people, amazing work, and I can't wait for more DLCs to come out. Just buy it!
Fun and relaxing, but I wish it had more content. It comes to an end too soon

Really fun and (most of the time) relaxing, some puzzles are questionable but overall it's a charming game. Absolutely wonderful game that I can definitely recommend if you want to relax, sort some items all while a fluffy cat tries to sabotage your work a few times!

Generally a nice casual game - though there are a few "optional" solutions (not so optional for completionists like me) that can have you scratching your head for a bit. However, there is just something satisfying about seeing something pop into a place that is made to hold that item and no other. Hoping for more levels...

There a couple of reasons why I am not keen on recommending the game. First being that some puzzle patterns are kind of random and frustrating (yes im talking about the stupid food on the trays that was a totally random order). Second, I am an achievement chaser, meanwhile some achievements are DLC exclusive wtf??? And lastly, this game is nowhere near worth 15 goddamn euros. Let alone another 6 euros for the DLC like?? did EA make this?

All in all, it was barely enjoyable and I had much higher expectations.

An entertaining and charming short and simple game that unfortunately frequently flirts between relaxing cathartic organization and frustrating OCD-esque nitpicking very quickly.
[hr][/hr]
I would not recommend based on:
Several instances of interactable elements randomly stopping responding, forcing a restart of the puzzle.
Many puzzles in certain chapters become trial and error; Chapter 5 is most egregious for this
An optional onscreen menu button would be appreciated for accessibility, ESC is the only key used on the keyboard
Hints are typically just flat out answers for 1 completion method, and kill immersion by requiring several steps to view and return to the puzzle: ESC>Hints>Manually erase scribbles on notepad>Onscreen 'X'>Resume) each step with a ~1-2 second animation that has to play
Getting 100% of the achievements requires both [u]100(!)[/u] [b]total[/b] and [u]30[/u] [i]consecutive[/i] days of completing a Daily Challenge level
Really liked this game, very satisfying.
very cozy game/

This game is sooooooo relaxing. I was really tired at work and I decided to play this game and I did not expect to be relaxed. It's so satisfying to organize items, arrange items by color, height, style, etc. The story of a cat trying to ruin the things I clean is so adorable and the end part of the game was so intense (at least for me) that I was shaking. I guess that part was not the chill part of this game, but it's still good.  I am so happy that some levels have multiple solutions which tickled my brain for possible answers and posed a challenge to my organizational skills. When I finished the game, I was sad it all ended. But I am happy for the daily tidies that still keep the game. Hoping to buy the DLC soon.
very cool so fun i love organizing

It's a pretty cute game that has puzzles, from simple to hard. There is no order on simple to hard, it's just sometimes hard and sometimes it's super easy and obvious. Solid 3/5 from me, however...

Don't get this game because it looks 'aesthetic' or 'cute.' Get it if you enjoy puzzles. Also, get it on sale. 20 seems too much for this and I'd rather buy it for 10.

I am not recommending this game because I don't think there's anything to do after completing the game. The 'daily tidy' is often reused levels. It ranges from making something look like a mirror of itself with plants to burning candles from long to short. That one package level will make you want to cuss the living hell out of the world.

I definitely do not recommend this game who aren't fans of puzzles, would make them want to roll their eyes of boredom or rip their hair out of rage.

edit: the cat though is a mood.
better than lexapro or zoloft stg
Very cute. It can be difficult sometimes, but most of the puzzles are fun and simple. You can get a hint each level or skip the level entirely without consequence.
Very fun and scratches that organizing itch

Really nice relaxing game - helps with my depression - would recommend to people who just want to escape for a bit
Only bad thing is that I wish there were more levels, or similar games like this one.

A great puzzle game! I love that this game combines the satisfaction of organizing with escape-room-like puzzles without the pressure of a timer. The levels are beautifully designed with a gradually increasing level of difficulty. I enjoy that there are multiple ways to solve several of the puzzles based on which patterns stand out the most at first glance. The hints are helpful without giving too much away. I especially love the mischievous cat and the levels where you can pet them!

I 100000% recommend this game. A Little to the Left is just so cozy and relaxing. And I believe it has a high replay-ably I replay it ALL the time. It does not get boring in my opinion. I would love more levels, I wish it was like Candy Crush with like 1000's of levels cause I would every SINGLE one. They even have the Daily Tidies, which is like a daily remastered version of the levels not in the DLC pack (but don't quote me on that not too sure if they used any from the DLC but I don't think so). You get one daily tidy a day and they are different everyday. I absolutely love this game, thank you Max Inferno and Secret Mode for this game!! :)
it is relaxing and frustrating at the same time there is more options to the end then i thought

marvelous....

fun game :D

some of the levels are a little weird but overall its a great game.

This game is extremely therapeutic, while also being a fun and challenging puzzle solver. The music is smooth and calming, the colors aren't super bright so it's easy on the eyes. and the sounds of dragging the items - top notch!

Definitely get this if you want something interesting, challenging, and calming to play.
Enjoyed this simple puzzle game, looking forward to more levels

very relaxing game
100% would recommend
Brain-twisting puzzles with cute illustrations and relaxing music.
Playing this game scratches that small, minuscule OCD part of my brain that desires to organize and fix.
Calm, relaxing and tests my mind in figuring out the puzzle. Only complaint is that I need more!! :)
i like satisfying myself

A very fun game, although slightly frustrating at times. I love the idea that puzzles can be solved in multiple different ways, just shows how complex it is.
