I love this game! In three terms: Feelgood, chill and aesthetically pleasing. Only wish there was more cause I love it and don't want it to be over :')
Very cute game, definitely recommend when you feeling like organizing and wanting to be relaxed. :>

Brought this game as i am organising freak and love to clean which is way for myself to cope with my stress. I play this when im feeling overwhelmed from the busy life. The music, the art, the colours, THE EVERYTHING is perfect. I love it, i wish there was more levels as i also downloaded the drawers & cupboards instalment and loved that too. 

Love from Tess.W in Australia.

Wonderful! The concept and the graphics are clever. The puzzles are different enough to make each one a small challenge. These are games to be savored, there are no timers, no points lost for using hints. There is a satisfaction in looking at a completely organized screen/completed puzzle that pushes you to the next level. I hope that there will be many versions of this game to come.

Absolutely love this game, I go in daily to do my tasks and relax.
I love how varied the puzzles are and I highly recommend for a chill experience.

This game isn't for everyone, I would say this game is for people who like a bit of both puzzles and organizing, if you strictly like one over the other than I wouldn't suggest this game. I say that because some of the puzzles require so weird, surreal logic and I know that isn't what everyone is looking for. I overall really enjoy this game, from the design to the puzzles, but I do have some criticisms of the game. Not everything I list is in any particular order nor does it mean this game is bad at all.

Pros: 
- I enjoy that some levels have one solution and others have multiple solutions. It stems from the idea that not everyone 
   organizes things the same, so with levels with books or stacks, I tended to organize them by thickness

- The colors and design are simplistic without having no distinct style. It also made it a bit easier on my eyes 

- Each chapter had a unique theme to organization that wasn't only limited to stationary. I personally liked this because I 
   enjoy all sorts of organizing 

- The cat is very cute and it adds little mischief to the game 

- I liked some of the challenges of the puzzles and some of the achievements are interesting. I enjoyed the surreal like 
   puzzles near the end of the game. It gave something more to the game

- Daily tidy is a cute feature and adds a layer to the game that makes it seems like a game I can come to consistently

Cons:
- Puzzles at the beginning of the game are easy, but can become more difficult and less logical. Finding other solutions 
   may also be difficult to understand. I didn't necessarily mind this but some of the hints for these levels didn't make much 
   sense to me

- Sometimes there isn't much distinction between some colors, making it a bit difficult for some puzzles

- Some achievements are not something you would even think of doing unless you look up how to get that achievement

A point I don't necessarily want to add is pricing. I personally have no issue with the pricing and I also got this game during the summer sale. I think there is a decent amount of content for the price and I know I'll play this game a lot, even when I do finish all of the levels and the achievements. However, I know pricing can be an issue for others and I do think the DLC on it's own is a bit too much and probably could've been added as part of the game. If pricing is really an issue for you for how much content is there in the base game, I would get it on a sale.

Overall, A Little to the Left is just a fun little puzzle game to pass yourself some time. As many people pointed out, however, some puzzles may seem counter intuative (e.g. you think the books need to be arranged by their height/width, but, in actuality, they need to be arranged using a tiny, almost unnoticable at first detail). Thankfully, there's usually a hint to guide you to, at the very least, one of the available solutions. There's also Daily Tidy, which gives you a daily challenge to complete and rewards for completing certain amounts of them, making getting the 100% completion slightly harder. Nevertheless, most of these barely deduct any fun from the gameplay. There's also plenty of calming music and a cat. 9/10, would recommend to anyone, regardless if you like the genre.
Edit: Having also just finished the (rather brief) DLC, I have to say that my opinion is largely unchanged. Some achievements in the game are somewhat glitched, sure, but that can be dealt with by reloading the game, so it's not a big deal.
Very satisfying to play and pretty smooth running.

A Little to the Left is definitely a favorite when it comes to puzzle games. 
Each level is unique with puzzles that are either super simple to solve or head scratching mysteries that take a little longer to solve.
The music was nice to listen to while trying to solve all of these puzzles.
The hint system doesn't give away too much when you use it, which is nice for those who want a little help, but not having the whole thing spoiled.
Also can't forget the best part about this game: There's a cat! 

DLC: Cupboards and Drawers:
The DLC is just like the base game with even more puzzles to test your mind and give you the "Oh! So Satisfying!" moments that your heart desires. They aren't too challenging, but if you are trying to go for that 100% completion like i did, you most likely will be there for a while guessing the possible answer. 
Oh! If you liked the cat from the base game, you do get to see them again in this DLC.

Overall, I'd highly recommend this to anyone looking for a decent puzzle game. It's slightly challenging, but it's still a lot of fun to play.

I had wanted to buy and play that game for a while, so my expectations were definitely high. I admire the art style - it's very cozy and I really enjoyed looking at everything. It made even the most mundane things cute. 
I agree that many puzzles in the main game are too easy and don't require a lot of logic, but they become trickier further in the game. I enjoyed that most of the levels had 2-3 different solutions, which made you think outside the box. It is a type of game that is perfect for relaxing after a hard day with a cup of tea (or a glass of wine). 
But I, like many others, found the game maybe a bit too short for that kind of money, even after purchasing the DLC. I thought that Daily Tidies would expand the game and provide some unique levels (considering that a new Daily Tidy becomes available only after 12 hours). But I was quite disappointed to discover that it is just repurposed levels of the main game. I don't really think it's fair that the makers of the game made almost half of the achievements for Daily Tidies. So, the players will have to wait months to 100% the game.
BANGER!!!!

I don't see many nuanced reviews on this game, which I don't quite get. I played the main game some time ago and just now got the DLC.

Let's start with the positives:
-It is an incredibly aesthetically pleasing game! Cute graphics, a nice art style, and a color palette that is very soothing on the eye without having that incredibly monotone beige thing going on or only being pastel. All in all: very pretty!
-The puzzles, overall, are quite nice. I love the cupboard Idea, I like the range in difficulty for the most part and as a casual, sometimes nicely tricky, puzzle game it is very nice. There are several levels where I went: "Oh that's a neat Idea!" after figuring it out
-I really like the puzzles with 3 or more answers, those were always fun

Now the negatives:
-For the price, especially the new DLC price, it is not enough gameplay by far. The DLC cost 6 euros and I almost felt robbed by the lack of content, there's only so much you can do with the concept, but we'll get to that
-Some Levels feel rushed or made with very little love. Levels like that Seashell ordering one don't have that sorting feeling that makes so much sense, where it might be tricky in parts, but generally intuitive. It felt like its simply the prettiest way of arranging the shells according to the makers. It just feels illogical... And I really hate that. Yes tricky, even very tricky is fine. But it has to be solvable, not through trial and error, but logic.
-please stop with the cat levels. It's a cute gimmick, but there were 3 or 4 (maybe more) so-called "levels" in the DLC that were simply clicking on the kitty to "pet" it. It felt like the makers were just trying to increase the level count in the DLC without more work.
-some levels with only one answer also feel like they were made for a 3rd grader. Cute, but not what I'd expect for that price
-very repetitive in parts, again I like the drawer-type sorting idea a lot, but not for it to be every level. Some ideas are just overdone without adding any new spin most of the time

All in all: I enjoyed this a lot while playing and was very excited about the DLC which immensely disappointed me in the end. It's cute, but thinking about it now it is very overpriced and it's just that: kinda cute, very pretty but nothing groundbreaking. Get it or don't get it, you're probably really gonna like it, but there is also a lot to improve and change and you're gonna have to live with that.

I LOVE this game. So satisfying and sometimes challenging.

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
You can pat the cat. /á  Ì¥  Ì®  Ì¥ áŸ\à¸…

[h1]Story / Character[/h1]
There is no plot to follow, it's just about cleaning up the house. The cat is cute though.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
You solve various puzzles by rearranging small parts of the house or cleaning in short levels. In between you can pet the cat from time to time. The puzzles aren't too difficult and repetitive in places, but never to the point that it bothered me.

[h1]Artstyle / Music[/h1]
The game looks a bit like it was drawn. The screenshots show the style pretty well.
The music is pretty simple, which is not a bad thing and suits the game quite well.

[h1]Bugs[/h1]
In the 12.8 hours I played, I didn't notice any bugs.

This game is amazing! If you like organizing and tidying this is absolutely the game for you. The puzzles range from simple to very challenging and there is a lot of content with the daily tidy. I keep playing my favorite levels over again because it is so calming. 10/10 all the way!

A Little to the Left has received mixed reviews from critics and players alike. While some have appreciated the game's unique concept and clever puzzles, others have expressed frustration with its challenging difficulty level, which they found to be a bit too unforgiving at times. The game's minimalistic art style, while praised for its charm, has also been criticized for lacking visual depth and variety. Additionally, a few players have noted that the game's controls can feel clunky and imprecise, leading to moments of unnecessary frustration. Overall, A Little to the Left offers an interesting puzzle experience, but its difficulty and control issues may hinder the enjoyment for some players.

Most puzzles are very intuitive to figure out and the game often supports multiple approaches to the same puzzle. I did not understand how the synchronized placement puzzles worked. These puzzles involved a few objects that you needed to place in a specific pattern on the screen and were very finicky. Even if you had everything in roughly the right place, you needed to do a lot of little adjustments for the game to recognize that you had solved it. Still, this was a minimal part of the game. If you enjoy calm puzzle and tidying games, like "unpacking", you'll enjoy this. Cat was also very cute.

A delicate blend of: cute, elegance, challenge, elegant design, and cat memes. The game is woefully short, but it makes up for it with a delicate charm. I found most of the puzzles to be "easy", in that it was clear what the game wanted you to do and how to do it. About 5% of the levels and additional solves required a bit of savvy but not in a way that would be frustrating for the user. This game was oddly calming for me while I've heard others say that the game feels frustrating. There is no time pressure here; take your time and find new ways to look at things. On a final note, I found the game's music to be mesmerizing, even luring. Any puzzle fan should have this game.

I'm not sure I would recommend buying the game at full price, but if it goes on sale for 9.99 or less than I think it would be worth the buy. The game is definitely satisfying, but that's it's biggest plus side, so if you don't care much for challenging gameplay and just want to relax, it's a worthwhile purchase. It feels like at least 10 or 20 puzzles were thrown in just for the sake of increasing the puzzle count (as an example, a few just involve rearranging three objects in order.) I would much rather have seen half as many puzzles that were challenging and well-thought out, but I cannot complain too much as there were at least 4 or 5 puzzles in the game that had me stumped for a few minutes. The "Daily Tidy" doesn't offer much in terms of replay value, but I can at least appreciate the developers' attempt to giving the game some sort of long-term playability. I would love to see a game that focuses solely on the compartment-sorting puzzles, as these ones (particularly the shed) felt satisfying to work through and solve, as well as being some of the only puzzles in the game that I didn't blow through in 30 seconds.

All in all, this is a cute game that I would highly recommend grabbing for under 10 if you can, but only expect a few hours of playtime total.
Loved the game, very simple but short finished way too quickly wish there were more levels or they were slightly more challenging so it would take longer to complete
Satisfying. Loved the part where you become an eldritch god.

TL;DR No this is not the most amazing puzzle game ever and no this is not a "sorting items into boxes" game like TikTok shows it, but it is still a fun and cute game.

TikTok videos of it may make you think it involves sorting items in draws or cases into their exact place and such, but that is only a small part of the total levels. That being said, it is an adorably designed puzzle games that follows a somewhat disjointed story of a person and their cat with a nice, quaint art style and enjoyable puzzles (some with multiple solutions). There are even daily puzzles to do so you can keep getting more to do. Additionally the levels are not super difficult, but are well designed, work well with the art style and have some unique mechanics.

Incredibly fun and satisfying game! Don't be afraid to use hints. Occasionally you'll be just slightly off of what they want you to do, even if you understand the puzzle. Hints can take away a lot of the frustration!

If, like me, you've got a bit of OCD then this game is for you. A little too quirky in places and often a bit frustrating but I loved every minute of it. It's basically putting stuff in order but it's cleverly done and I shall await the next DLC with eager anticipation. Nicely priced too as I felt I'd got my monies worth on both the original game and the DLC which I bought the moment I'd finished the game. Looking forward to more of the same from this developer.
its really cute and fun but if you don't like organizing its probably not for you and i did get frustrated on one or two level but overall very fun

this is the perfect puzzle game. it's non-conventional, challenging, interest-piquing, and best of all very forgiving when you don't understand the goal right away. the art is delightful, the themes are universal, and god do i love that cat. i'm so delighted and impressed. i finished the entire doors and cupboards DLC in one sitting because i was so immersed, heh. i anticipate releases from this developer in the future!

Adorable tasks and puzzles! The style is very soft to the eyes and very simple/cute !! The music is also very nice and calm and the sound effects for picking up/setting down the objects is also really nice!  (âœ¿â— â€¿â— )
I loved playing this through, and I'll definitely be playing it again. $10 was worth the 5 hours of play time with the ability to play through again and figure out the other solutions

A nice cozy game with just enough challenge to keep your brain busy and satisfy the little creature in the back of your skull that likes to organize things arbitrarily. Were you a kid that liked to line up your toys instead of play with them? This is the game for you! Like to put puzzles together but don't want to have a puzzle sitting on your table for days? The game for you! There's enough variety in levels to have something to satisfy everyone, and the DLC only adds more. 

it makes my monkey brain go ooga booga shapes and colors
I actually was trying to hold back tears when I finished the game, it's such a beautiful experience

Very pleasant and simple puzzle game. Haven't had such a calm time with video games in a long time honestly. Solutions are well explained through hints you can use if you get stuck and most of the levels you can just outright skip. The only two things I dislike are the plant symmetry puzzles and the daily tidy achievements. 

The plant symmetry puzzles are horribly explained, difficult to keep track of, and can easily soft-lock you even once you know what you're doing. It's not very fun in the slightest and more annoying than anything. This could've been easily fixed by avoiding locking selections permanently once made and instead highlighting the ones you want to keep. That way the outliers that grow back can be easily identified and if you select one by mistake you can simply undo the selection. 

The daily tidy on the other hand is a perfectly fine feature by itself, but what really sucks is that the achievements require you to go on [b]month long streaks[/b] and check in for [b]100 days.[/b] That's just stupid. I personally will probably do it anyways just cuz I find this game very fun, but grinding achievements aren't fun.

As long as you aren't achievement grinding and skip the second plant symmetry puzzle, it's a very relaxing and fun experience. Definitely would recommend!
really hope they make more levels! So relaxing and calm, great game.
it gud
good for relax
onnragaize
SO FUN
Super cool!  Highly recommend, and I'm not a gamer.

Calming and satisfying. If you're the kind of person who likes to sit and tidy, this scratches that itch without having to move anything. No instructions at all, and that surprisingly adds to the fun.
the cat that shows up is the best part of the game
Kitty cat

This game is so fun if you like organizing and puzzle games! I kept seeing it on TikTok and decided it was about time I finally bought it. As soon as I finished it (which it has about maybe 3-4 hours of game play depending on how in depth and accurate you want to play) I purchased the DLC. The DLC contains more difficult puzzles and itself probably has about 1-2 hours of game play! I'm currently in the process of getting all achievements! I love this game <3

From the store page I thought this would be a satisfying & cozy logic-based game for a neurodivergent person like myself to play, but as the game progresses the levels make less and less sense, and playing becomes a frustrating experience. I found myself placing items over and over again until I heard the "Ding" noise to indicate they were placed correctly in order to beat the levels as there was no logic to where they needed to be placed. 

I expected there to be more levels like the ones shown in the game preview where you organize things neatly. Instead there were a bunch of random tasks like the one where you tilt picture frames (not center, but tilt them diagonally to the side) which I found confusing as the game says to organize things in a pleasing way, and the way it wanted me to organize these was just distressing.

Also, even when I followed the hints to arrange items as portrayed in the hint, I was still not able to pass some of the levels. I feel like this would be a better game if it just allowed you to organize things to a satisfying degree, and you can just click continue. Unfortunately I would not recommend this game.
I love this game, it's super chill and gets your brain working
very good, i love love it!!!!!

A nice concept, but far too many puzzles just don't explain themselves well at all.  For example there's a pegboard where you hang tools, but it's entirely unclear what the points on the tools are that will  interact with the pegs, sometimes going so far as communicating with the player incorrectly that some parts CANNOT be used to hang the tools because they don't grip.. until you find the one place that they can.

The game is at its best when the puzzles are extremely simple and obvious and just pleasant to advance through.  The trickier ones are just poorly tuned.  Puzzle design is hard, but if you choose to make a puzzle game that's the stuff you have to get right.

The game includes hints, which is a good idea.  However, most of them are really not hints at all, just showing you the solution state instead of giving you a hint as to how to get there.  As a result, for some puzzles, the "hint" leaves nothing for you to consider at all, just copy the layout.  For others, it gives you no help at all, as you still have no idea how to achieve that layout, even if you might have already been trying to achieve it. As above, hinting for puzzles requires laborious play-testing, but it's simply part of delivering quality puzzle experiences.

---

I will add that the DLC gets a lot right that the base game did not.  It would probably be more worth it to buy the DLC without the base game if that was an option, but it's not.

Some of the answers are a little less intuitive than others, I do wish the hint wasn't only for the "first" answer as that's often the easiest one. But it's a good game, most of the puzzles you can figure out by just clicking around

Definitely fun to play with friends, solving puzzles together and working on achievements was the highlight of this game for me. This is the best kind of negative review because my biggest issue is that I liked the game so much I need MORE of it.
I really enjoyed this game while it lasted, but it is WILDLY short. I bought the game on sale and still don't feel like I got my moneys worth. The credits started rolling and I said, "Wait, that's it?" I might give the DLC a go, and the daily puzzles are nice, but man, there's really not at all a lot of content. I can't buy games SUPER often so when I do, I want it to last.
Out of the 4.4 hours the game has been open, I think about 3 of that was actual gameplay- including at least 5 daily puzzles. 

I suggest this game if you have the spare $15 and are only looking for a few hours of puzzles, or if you're new to puzzle games and it takes you a good while time to solve them. If you're looking for a full game that'll take you days or weeks to finish, or you can only buy games every so often, I wouldn't get this. I also don't suggest this for serious/hardcore puzzle players- while the puzzles are great, you'll whiz through this in less than half a day.

Other notes:
+The art is wonderful. The way the game is drawn is so lovely and perfect for a puzzle game.
+The vibes are cozy. This is a great game to play on a rainy day off, snuggled up in bed.
+I love the idea behind the game of constantly having to fix what a mischievous cat messes up, and I love that we see the cat so much!
+The puzzles DO make you think- there are a few general ideas they tend to reuse, but for the most part, each puzzle is solved in unique, interesting ways you don't see in many other puzzle games.
+The devs clearly love this game and it comes through. I appreciate that, and many others will, too. I feel better about spending the money on this game knowing it went to a great team- even if I'm not thrilled about the game itself.
-The hints are useless 90% of the time. They either do nothing, or they just completely solve the puzzle for you- there is no in between. Giving players the answers is not "a hint."
-The hints just solving the puzzle for you is extra frustrating because the puzzles give you no nods or hints as to what the goal of the puzzle is- there's several puzzles you solve and go "How the f*** was I supposed to know that was the goal?" It would be great if there were ACTUAL small hints, for example: "Size," "Color," "Lines." Not enough to just give you the answer like the hints do, but enough to give you a slight direction to figure out what the hell you're supposed to be doing with the stuff in front of you. So its either you figure it out completely alone, or you have the puzzle solved for you with their "hints"- there's no gray area. 

Overall, this is a great first step for what I feel is a fantastic indie dev team, and while A Little to the Left was not what I wanted it to be, I will definitely be keeping an eye out for future titles.
This game is so relaxing, I love the art style. Some of the puzzles really make me think, even though a lot of the time puzzles are easy. These ones really make you think.
Very satisfying game. Needs more dlcs
the regular organizing puzzles are great, however there's way too many "guess and pray" pattern puzzles that don't have any indication of the correct way to do them

Great and satisfying, but there are puzzles that are thrown in that seem just for filler, such as the symmetry ones. I also found it annoying that on puzzles with multiple solutions, the game would auto proceed you to the next level when you should have the choice to retry or not.
fucking amazing i love it sm

I've played unpacking for 11 hours even though, there's only 4 hours worth of game content. I've played this game for 2 hours or so but I will not be returning to this one. I hoped this game would have had more intricate organization "puzzles" rather than weirdly specific "patterned" puzzles. Welp onto the next game.
Super fun, one of a kind puzzle game.

It's a very relaxing yet challenging game. And the best part is that for most of the puzzles, there's more than one way to solve them, so you can keep going back and trying new ways. There's still some puzzles that I have no clue how to solve, even with the hints haha. The DLC is highly worth it.
boring just watch someone play it on yt
Very satisfying & cosy highly recommend <3
A great game, just wishing it was longer!! Definitely worth it
cat
Cozy OCD Simulator... with a cat!

I absolutely adore this game. Every time I find it hidden in my steam library I open it and play through again. It's a real stress reliever - the music, the levels, and especially the cats. I recommend getting this and the DLC... Very worth it.
Itched my brain good

I bought the game as well as the Drawers and Cupboards DLC. I think it's a fun game of solving puzzles, some of which have multiple ways to solve. The puzzles range in difficulty and there are different things that the levels look for (ex, some look for color coding and others look for sorting by size) so it doesn't feel like you're just replaying the same puzzle over and over. 

My only complaint is with some levels in the DLC. There are some glitches (specifically one that doesn't recognize when I do everything needed for the "A Balanced Meal" achievement), and -in my opinion- too many levels where there is no puzzle, just petting the cat. The puzzles in the DLC are more complex and layered, so I don't feel like the DLC was a waste of money but it was disappointing to see that there were less puzzles than I thought.
I LOVE ORGANIZING !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
I love organizing and this game gave me time to sort out items in a relaxing and aesthetic way. Highly recommend.
Very fun game, good mechanics and some incredibly good head scratchers as well
100 days well spent to 100% this game

This is a great game if you like relaxing and organizing. The only unfortunate thing for me is that there is not much variety in the daily tidies.

However, both the main game and the DLC are satisfying and well designed :)

Really enjoyable and cozy puzzle game with a mischievous cat for fans of Unpacking. Most puzzles are incredibly intuitive, especially once you take the time to explore a bit without hints. Would just recommend purchasing when on sale because playthrough is very quick, which makes its higher price point feel a bit inflated unless you plan to take the time to 100% everything.
Very good and oddly uplifting for me.

Imagine you're going for a walk, listening to music that fits the vibe. Amazing day with wonderful smells passing through the wind. Completely satisfied with your life and in the moment you feel like everything is just right. This game gives me that feeling. Tremendous

really fun puzzle game! my one complaint is that for puzzles with multiple solutions there is only one hint available. often times i find the solution given in the hint on my own but i am struggling with the other possible solution and the hint is no help since ive already completed that solution.

I did not enjoy playing this partially due to my own bias and partially due to the game itself. I was searching for something that gave me a Unpacking feel and it didn't deliver. It felt more like a mobile game, I half expected ads between puzzles. I projected expectations of a hinted story, of a throughline, of a leisurely fun experience which is not their fault and why I'd prefer to just give it a "meh" rating.

What I hated about it however is the puzzles themselves. 90% of them were garbage to me.
Sometimes they were so easy and straight forward I felt irritated by the fact I spent $20 on the game while other puzzles were such a leap up in 'difficulty' I would try every dumb option first expecting more dumb baby puzzles and eventually get so annoyed I'd check the hints and realise it was something I would have tried if I wasn't used to just stacking things by size. The erratic nature of what solved a puzzle took me out of thinking for myself - I would try to think about what they would want from me instead, fail, and then have to check the hints. 

And then the hints were never hints - they were the full solutions. Where is the fun in that? Where is the puzzle?? Add in the fact that sometimes the solutions were arbitrary - like I found a way to fit things in perfectly but it was wrong and I'd have to fix it to their solution given but there was no reason for it. The cutlery drawer infuriated me because the little spatula going with the big one, where it fit, made sense and the solution they gave made the pieces overlap so it isn't fitting what on earth.. lol I just really am not having a good time with this. I'm annoyed, which was the opposite of my intention going in.

I'm continuing to play for a bit longer, by god I'll get my money's worth, but I just finished a puzzle where my answer was theirs and yet it won't mark it as correct to move on. I have posted a side by side of my answer and the solution online and no one can figure out what is wrong BECAUSE THEY ARE THE SAME. 

EDIT IN - A few minutes later there was a puzzle where the answer was to just place leaves and such symmetrically and there are infinite answers but only one is their 'correct' way. There's no pattern to it or anything, it's just trying to guess how they in specific laid it out. It's not a puzzle, it's a guessing game. This game is giving me rage like I have not experienced since childhood lol and I am uninstalling it.

You hear little dings when you have something in the right place. So I know that I am not just missing something. I'm into chapter 2 and so far there have been 4 puzzles I have solved but game refuses to acknowledge that I have done so. I have no choice but to "skip" them even though I solved them. It's very frustrating.  There is one level where you move picture frames. I knew exactly where they wanted it moved to but for whatever reason you couldn't "hold" the frame long enough or once you got it close you would just let go and the picture would fall back to it's starting place. The game is supposed to be casual and relaxing. Instead it's frustrating. I'd let it go for the good levels but the game was nearly 20 and for that much money I'd prefer it work as intended and not have this many bugs.

As described on the box, it's a fun game. DLC was a nice addition. Most of the puzzles are simple enough, with a few outliers absolutely doing my head in. The dev team is small, so what they've achieved is doubly impressive.

All that said, I want to 100% the game, and the "100 Daily Tidy's" achievement is absolute hell. The entire concept of the daily puzzles is poorly implemented as it is just the same puzzle over and over, with variations in colour. The constellation puzzles should absolutely have different coloured stars for the ones you can move, and the plant puzzles are just annoying.

Overall, recommend. If you want to 100% know that you can change the date on your PC to mop up the daily achievements, but...it won't be fun. It has tarnished my enjoyment of the game, but I can recognise that I was enjoying it much more before this grind.

[b]To start:[/b] Be bullied by a cat.

[u]The Positives[/u]
+ Order and chaos collide in a puzzle game that involves a lot of tidying up.
+ A bright, colourful artstyle that, along with the music, makes for a relaxing experience.
+ While it includes optional hints, there's also the ability to outright skip any puzzles that don't appeal.
+ Several puzzles have more than one solution, an example is that along with ordering books by their height, they can also be ordered by colourâ€”it's up to the player to try things out.

[u]The Negatives[/u]
- Completionists beware: a hundred days of daily tidies are required for achievements, and this is time consuming even when changing the date on your computer. Not necessarily a bad thing, but most likely more time will be spent doing this than the main game itself.
- Some of the puzzles aren't great, their solutions either hard to decipher or the positioning of objects a bit too fiddly.

[b]To end:[/b] Look, hopping on every day to complete a quick puzzle is a nice idea, I just don't think there should be achievements tied to it. Opinions are my own and reflect my experience.

A little to the left is a casual puzzle/organizational game. The game has minimal story but throughout the five main chapters of the game players will be given hints to a cat in the background or within puzzles themselves that make common messes. This however is about the extent the game has as a story. 

The puzzles are for the most part fairly simple with a few levels each chapter having multiple solutions. It should be noted that for players who are expecting more of an organizational puzzle game that only makes up a small portion of the main games levels. There are actually more of those types of levels in the DLC.
Each chapter follows a common theme, with my personal favorite being the third as it had more of those aforementioned organizational puzzles. The final level was my least favorite but I'll touch on that more in a moment. The main overall puzzle make-up of the game consists of sorting by color, height, and object type. The puzzles themselves are not difficult, with the exception of a few that are a bit more of a brain teaser.

The final chapter however started to divert its puzzles from what the previous chapters had shown including: a time based puzzle for petting the cat, a Tetris like stacking puzzle, along with a few tasks that held the simplicity of the first couple of levels. The overall feel of the game completely changed for me and honestly, wasn't really what I was hoping for from the game. The first time I completed the game I remember thinking to myself "That's it?" The ending was so completely out of left field that I didn't really know how to feel about it. This would be my main complaint overall as the rest of the gameplay was actually quite enjoyable.

Then we get to the achievements, while the majority of them are not difficult, there are a few things to note for those who care about them. First you will need the DLC to 100% this game, and second a good almost fourth of the achievements have to do with a function called "daily tidy". This is a once every 24 hour daily puzzle players can do, and is based on a variety of smaller puzzles present in the game. The catch for achievement hunters is that you have to do 100 of these in order to get 100% in the game. In addition, 30 of those days you have to do consecutively. I'm all for achievements in a game, but I'm a firm believer that they should all be accessible within a standard playthrough. I shouldn't have to open up a game for a 5 minute puzzle long after finishing the game for achievements. You can mess with your local date and time to circumvent this, but that on its own just isn't worth the headache it would ultimately create.

Despite the couple of issues I have personally with the game, it is still a solid organizational puzzle game that completes what it set out to do. While the game does feature some "make-it-all-fit" puzzles they are only a small fraction of the full game and should not be what players expect the majority of gameplay to be. Those that are fine with this will likely find a cute, heartwarming, cozy puzzle game to spend a few hours to complete. Cat lovers/owners as well will more than likely resonate with quite a few of the cats interactions to prevent players from being able to tidy or clean in a few levels.

a great game to unwind if you're a cozy gamer. each puzzle brings something new to the table and it's fun to figure out all the possible solutions. it also provides helpful hints that can help struggling players, and i like how you can choose to only erase part of the hint if you only need help with part of the puzzle. the base game campaign is tons of fun but i will say that it's a bit short. if you can afford it, then buy it full price, but if you can't, then i highly recommend buying it on sale <3

the dlc is also very nice and simple. it didnt stray far from the original game and it really just felt like an add-on with more levels, just like you'd expect.

my only criticism would be the daily tidy. i think the 100-day tidies is an excessive achievement. especially since the daily tidies are simply remakes of a handful of puzzles from the campaign (maybe 10 or so puzzles).  i understand the concept of the daily tidies and i like the idea of "doing something small each day," but it really just felt repetitive.  while the campaign is fresh and rewarding, the daily tidies are just monotonous and repetitive.

a tip for any fellow completionists: you can simply change the time on your computer to skip to the next days' tidies. (there's a great guide by D.A.R.K. if you look at the community forum's guides!)

as for anyone else who's read this far, i recommend time travelling to 12/27/2022 to try the five special holiday tidies! they were super fun and unique :) i hope they bring it back this year!

and of course, thank you devs for all the work you put into this game <3 despite my criticism towards the daily tidies, i had an absolute blast!! i ended up 100%-ing the game in just 4 days haha

[list]
[*]Puzzles that rely on pure trial and error, especially the ones that require you to put objects into an incredibly specific spot with no width/height indication. Combine this with the puzzles that require you to do the same thing three times, and it's even worse.
[*]Bizarre 15-minute "dream sequence" ending that goes on far too long and feels like it's padding playtime than having a conclusion to your busy work. Feels like they ran out of ideas and decided to give us lunchbox Tetris instead.
[*]A cat that destroys your progress after you finish. Sure, it might simulate what a real cat is like, but there's a reason why modern puzzle games give you infinite time to think about your next action.
[*]A daily streak achievement: 365 days total and 30 days consecutively on launch. The reason why I am on my PC and not my mobile phone is because I don't want the game I'm playing to beg for my attention with known psychological hooks.
[*]The menus. You can't retry a level after beating it unless you've already done it before (only useful for 3 solution levels) and pressing the X to return locks you into this painfully slow scroll where you watch the screen slide horizontally across every level you've completed. Just allow me to skip it, please.
[/list]
[b]Why? At best, these don't help the game in any way, and at worst show a lack of game direction and mindfulness toward the player experience.[/b]

But what really ruins the game? The rattle cat toy doesn't make a sound when you grab and shake it, only when you pick up and drop it. Unpacking did this perfectly, how did they mess this up?

Absolutely adorable, and the puzzles are fun and interesting. I do wish that the hints were a little less....obvious I guess? I feel more like I'm getting the answer instead of getting a hint. But I really like the variety in puzzle types, the various ways to solve the same level, and of course the cat. With the new update, I'm sad they took away the bigger daily tidy achievements. A big part of what motivated me to play everyday was the longer stretch goals and desire to get the harder achievements, and with one update I'm basically done already. I think that more, smaller intervals should have been added instead of nerfing the big achievements. Sure, it's a cozy game, but achievements are just that. An achievement, they don't have to be super easy.

I do appreciate them listening to other feedback and fixing things like the contrast between items in the symmetry levels.

DLC Update: It is not worth $6. The new types of puzzles are awesome but 4 out of the 25 new levels are...petting the cat once. I like a good petting the cat mechanic but if you're going to sell a DLC that takes about 45min to 100% you shouldn't count those 4 levels. I enjoyed playing it, but it is so not worth the money.

There's really two main puzzles to the game: 

1) Figure out how exactly they want you to solve the puzzle
2) Figure out where, _exactly_, they want you to place the pieces

But the unforgivable thing is that it requires audio to be on to receive confirmation of a correctly placed puzzle piece. There is no option to toggle any type of visual indicator. [h1]"A Little to the Left" is a laid-back puzzle game.[/h1]

UPDATE FOR DLC: DLC has no reflex shenanigans. Not many mind benders but a great collection of chill sorting puzzles that leans into the game's unique selling points. (Also I went back for an achievement run and go AFK a lot, so don't judge game length off of my playtime. It's no where near that long.)

--

There's no "aim for perfect" with move or time limits or what have you, just getting the solution. (And sometimes double-clicking to confirm the solution because an item is slightly out-of-place.)
There's some Steam achievements that offer more challenge, but they're not reflected in the game.

Most other games with similar 'vibes' to this one tend to be story-based. A Little to the Left isn't story based - it's just a series homely or artsy scenes with patterns to identify. It's the cozy puzzle game equivalent of a daily crossword.

[b]A quick list of games you may also like:[/b] "inbento", "Freshly Frosted", "Assemble With Care", "Fossil Corner", "Behind the Frame", and, yes, "Unpacking".

I understand why people compare it to "Unpacking" -- it's a well-known game and both games aim for the  satisfaction of 'tidying', but the comparison sets false expectations. "A Little To the Left" chases the satisfaction of a "ding!" when you find a solution. Of noticing something could line-up and then making it so, regardless of function.
If you want to scratch the exact same itch as "Unpacking" then you may want to look at simulator titles like "House Flipper" where you're less trapped by the whims of Puzzle Game Logic(TM).

I find this game is at its best when you're tidying domestic scenes, and its worst when you're playing spot-the-difference symmetry. There's only a few of those levels and they're fortunately (for me) far out-weighed by levels based on categorisation and shape-matching. Those levels make up most of the game, with some inventive ones scattered in-between. 

The cat's a cute occasional nemesis. It appears too rarely for me to get particularly annoyed at it, and it's more like a puzzle game mini-boss. It DOES herald the only reaction-based portions of the game though. (Remember you can skip levels if this is a hurdle for you.)

[hr][/hr]
Note: my game time is inflated by 1-2 hours because I wandered off to clean the kitchen. Whoops.

Let me start with why I wouldn't recommend this game: Even on sale, there are simply not enough unique, challenging puzzles to justify the price tag.

This game has a ton of strengths: the art style and sound design are phenomenal, the cat is adorable, and there are certainly some very clever and satisfying puzzles. The issue lies in the fact that a majority of the puzzles are so straightforward, repeat an idea that's already been seen multiple times without new mechanics, or aren't even puzzles (petting the cat was cute once, but realizing that multiple of the levels being advertised were clicking on the cat took me aback). I really enjoyed it for the first half, but when I realized the game wasn't actually progressing in difficulty at all, I became more annoyed.

All of the promotions and advertisements that led me to purchase this game were puzzles relating to sorting drawers, cabinets, etc. From reading the reviews, it seems that was a common motivator- the satisfying puzzles where a pair of scissors fits in a perfect spot and whatnot. I loved these levels, and actually disagree with a lot of the reviews saying they were too nuanced or nonsensical. I felt that these levels perfectly built on the simple skills taught in the basic puzzles and combined them, so you found yourself wondering "does this need to be in color order? Are there indents indicating a numerical order?" These were the moments that felt like the price was justified and even if the game was 50% these levels, I would recommend it. However, it's not. The majority of the puzzles take less than a minute, some even less than 30 seconds, and often repeat the exact same principle over and over again. Shockingly, they get even simpler and more repetitive in the final chapters of the game, which caught me super off guard. This game has the perfect opportunity to build on concepts and combine them, increasing in difficult as it proceeds, and actually demonstrates that it's capable of it in the drawer levels. Instead, the ending feels like a tunnel of doing the same 3 puzzles over and over until the credits roll, and I hardly felt accomplished by the ending of the base game or DLC.

Perhaps the most overwhelming feeling I got from this game: If you removed the puzzles that repeated or were so straightforward you had to pause and reflect on how much money you spent on it, this game feels like a truly excellent mobile/tablet game that you would pay a few dollars for or get with a subscription and have a great time playing. I completed a single star on every level in the base game and DLC in under 4 hours (removing time spent with the game open while I stepped away, etc.), which is one of the poorer ratios cost to content I've seen from similar titles. The DLC has about the ratio of challenging to basic puzzles I would expect from the entire game.

I can't emphasize enough that this game oozes the love that was put into it- there was clearly so much passion and thought put into so many elements, and I really wanted to love it. Based on the DLC, it seems to be heading in the right direction, but I don't think I could justify spending any more money on additional levels.

It's very cute and the sound design is very nice. It's good, it's great! Very satisfying! But my personal experience was a bit lackluster. I was hoping for something else from it, more of a satisfying sandbox where you can arrange things in a way that makes sense to you. And this is more of a puzzler, where you spend most of your time trying to figure out how the [i]game[/i] wants you to arrange things. Sometimes the solutions felt too arbitrary to me. ("Why can this item go here and not this other visually similar item?" "Why can't I organize these things by color/size/pattern after just doing that in a similar level?")

I really wanted to love it, but it just isn't for me.

Overall, A little to the left is a wonderful puzzle game, flawed only by a few things:

Many of the puzzles require too much precision. You will have everything correct but one battery is a pixel out of place. Thre should be more allowance for this to cut down on frustration. There's also some levels where it's difficult to figure out where to start and all the pieces of the puzzle are in a pile. In actual puzzle building you can see all your pieces but not in this game which makes starting very difficult in places.

The other flaw is that the best levels in the game (drawer organizing) are few and far between. Considering I bought the game for those levels, I would do anything for a level pack of 20 or so of just drawer organizing. 

Overall I'd still recommend this game jsut go in knowing that the drawer levels are not that common and someof the puzzles you will solve but because there's a pixel off, you can't get the puzzle to ding and give you the star. You can skip the level but it's still frustrating. 

More drawer levels please!!

I was interested in the game after playing the demo, and I like the game, but if you're looking for a similar experience to Unpacking this might not be it. The first chapters hit that vibe for me, but the later chapters have more "there is only one solution" puzzles, and some of them are just kind of confusing. Though I don't think any of the puzzles have any completely out of nowhere solutions, sometimes it does feel like you just have to do what the game wants despite finding another satisfying way (and there's still one puzzle solution I cannot figure out the logic behind, but only that one) I was hoping for more multiple solution puzzles, but they only make up about a fourth of the campaign puzzles. Also the ending was weird and I think it went on for a bit too long, but it was very pretty.


I recommend the game still, it's a very relaxing and pretty puzzle game. The majority of the puzzles are good, and there's a cute cat.

I like puzzle games, I really do. 
I am a big fan of the Professor Layton games; I have played all of them. Those games are known for having a lot of really good puzzles and some bad ones that you cant possibly follow their logic. This game has some really good puzzles that make you feel really good for figuring them out, and a LOT of bad ones that are even worse than the worst puzzles from Professor Layton.
The repetitive nature of some of the puzzles only worsen when you have to solve them multiple times and even worse when you have to do them again and again and again with the daily puzzles that simply change the assets. 

I honestly cannot recommend this game because each time I played it, I just ended up frustrated by how it was.

If you like it, that is wonderful it just means I couldnâ€™t enjoy something you did. And in the end that is more important than anything else. I just didnâ€™t enjoy it.

well, i got what i expected. 

if you've played the demo - yep, that's pretty much the game, just with more puzzles. it's fun. i suspect i will revisit the levels that have you organising things into obvious places, as those are the most satisfying and genuinely relaxing to me. 

however, some of the puzzles don't really have a good way to figure out what you're supposed to do without using the hints, which is frustrating (the opposite of what i wanted from this game). on top of that, sometimes the answers to the puzzles have incredibly specific placement, and i found myself having to adjust objects even when things visually looked to be lined up.

and with my hours played i have 100% completed the main levels. 

if you're a completionist, watch out - there are daily puzzles that expire after 24 hours, and an achievement for 365 of them. it's not going to be a quick completion. (this is no longer the case, thanks devs for lessening the requirements for some of the achievements :D)

i must also stress that while i enjoyed the game and can recommend it, i don't think it was worth 23 AUD. it's worth playing, but wait for it to be on sale.

[h1]5/10[/h1] For people with insane amounts of patience. Some levels are great - the ones where you sort things into a tray, drawer etc. You see the shape of each compartment so you actually have a goal to work towards. "Good" levels are rare. Some levels have such obscure solutions you actually need a guide. You can't even skip levels... why?? Great visuals. There is no freedom to how you want to place items. If you find a solution which is better, but isn't the "right" one - you can't complete the level.

Saw a Tik Tok of this game. Some dude putting stuff in boxes trying to make it fit.  Thought ah, yes, something to please my inner extra-perfection itch. Sadly it only had a few of these type puzzles. Left utterly disappointed. And of course the game is on a lil sale after i buy it full-price. 

[b] The game [/b] itself is very short. It starts with easy solutions, then moves into some-what more thinking puzzles and the end? what the hell is with the end? It felt like devs just ran out of ideas or were in a rush to get somewhere. Cause last chapter was just not it. Especially since the game itself is short, the end should've been more worked on, to get that rewarding feeling or something.

[b] DLC [/b] felt more like what i expected from this game. Yet again, short, but it filled the holes main game had.

[b] The price [/b] is way too much for such game. If you really want this game I suggest waiting for a sale. It is overpriced for what you getting. It should've been the price of DLC, though DLC was kind of worth those pennies comparing their game-DLC price ratio.

[b] Daily tidy [/b] is something else man. You would expect, since you have to do 100 of them for the achievement, it would be something different each day, to make you want to do them each day. Something cool, unique and thinking required to make you turn on you PC, launch the game only for the daily tidy and go on about your day, and do that all over again for 100 days. Wrong. The puzzles are the easiest and shortest ones taken out of the main game, changed a bit (different colors, objects) and repeats themselves every other day for 100 days. Luckily [spoiler] you can manipulate it by manually changing date on your PC, so that you don't have to wait and spare your time for those 100 days [/spoiler]

[b] Overall [/b] the game is not worth its price. Few puzzles were interesting, and others - mid.

i wanted to like this game, i did. but i guess i felt a little misled about the advertising. instead of being about organizing and a cat, it was a puzzle game with effectively no story. the puzzles themselves range from easy to infuriating, as the puzzle system can be very sensitive. so i would get stuck and get frustrated, and have to fully mute the game to try and figure it out. i returned the game for a refund.

I love it! I just finished playing it, and I played it slowly over the course of about 2 months, only completely 1 or 2 puzzles at a time, playing once a week or so, very casually, until the last couple days when I had some time to play more. It is indeed a short game but I found it very enjoyable, but I can see how it wouldn't be for everyone. I love puzzles and I LOVE sorting and organizing things. The nature of the puzzles, the music, and the art were very soothing for me. I've been having kind of a rough time with life lately and this game was a very comforting way to "problem solve" and sort of zen-out. 

Like some other reviews have said, the control/cursor can be a little annoying sometimes. I only struggled with a handful of the puzzles, in terms of being completely stumped at what angle to solve it from, and usually if I step away and come back to the game later or another day, with fresh eyes, I was able to solve it. A couple times I resorted to using hints.

overall, if you like puzzles and sorting, and you like chill music and cute pastel art, i'd recommend this. I hope they release more games like this or a follow up, because I could happily keep enjoying this for a long time.

Wonderful game, music, and gameplay :) love the cat that shows up throughout, & the ending. Devs are very good with responding to and dealing with suggestions or issues, very kind and straightforward about things when reached out to. Generally just a wonderful game <3

Several puzzles I would use the hint just because the game wasn't recognizing my answer, and the hint would depict the exact solution I had performed that wasn't being accepted. No thank you, my blood pressure doesn't need this.

A Little to the Left is a comfy little puzzle game that provides a nice and novel experience that hits close to home.  It is easy to pick up and hard to put down, and by the end of it, youâ€™ll be taking pride in the spaces youâ€™ve cleaned.  

The premise is simple: every puzzle consists of a mess that needs to be cleaned.  The game does not explicitly describe how that must be accomplished, so the player must inductively determine what â€œcleanâ€ means.  However, I think youâ€™ll find that most of the puzzles click quite easily, as everything is grounded in the cleaning of everyday things.  The patterns are intuitive and rewarding, and even if you donâ€™t see it, the game allows you to obtain hints and/or skip any level.  It really is an accessible game that anyone and everyone can appreciate.

The one thing I wish was that the game was longer.  I want more, and the new DLC will rectify this problem, but it really does leave a mark on you.  The game does provide â€œDaily Tidies,â€ a randomly generated daily level, but it isnâ€™t sufficient.  They are just randomizations of the levels in the main campaign, so they can become boring quickly.

Some believe that the game is too short for its price, but I would disagree.  Overall, even at full price, I wholeheartedly believe it is worth every dollar.  It may be short, but the experience, the challenge, itâ€™s all unforgettable.  I would highly recommend this game, and I canâ€™t wait for the DLC!

There were a few levels in A Little to the Left that I really enjoyed. But I was hoping for more organization gameplay, like Unpacking, instead of just another basic puzzle game. Most of the level have nothing to do with organizing or fixing anything. You just fumble around until you figure out what the puzzle wants you to do. I'm not a fan of these types of games and feel they never really hit the balance between providing a challenge but also giving you enough information to go on.

If you like an average puzzle game where you have to figure out what the game is actually asking you to do before you can even attempt to know the answer, this is probably for you. But even still, it's definitely overpriced. This would be better around the 4.99usd mark.

[b]Constructive critiques for this game[/b]
- The cursor design and click detection are quite poor, especially when playing on a laptop track pad or the steam deck. I found myself getting a little frustrated with this.
- There is a point in the game where you are unable to skip a 'cutscene' in order to continue on. It isn't long, but this would have been a nice feature. I wasn't a fan of the time it took to move from one puzzle to the next.
- Many of the puzzles feel like pure 'filler' and are not challenging, nor interesting. For example there are countless 'symmetry' puzzles, where you're given some amount of shapes and need to create symmetry along a central Y axis.  This disappointed me, because there were many puzzles that felt quite cheeky/clever otherwise. 

At ~5 casual hours in length the game serves its purpose well, but I wouldn't classify it as [i]challenging[/i] or a 'must buy' puzzler. I appreciate the trance the game put me in, and there's a lot of love put into this. So worth the $15, and even better if you can get it on sale.

Idk if it's my autism messing things up for me or what, but my (mis?)understanding of A Little to the Left going in was that this would be a super chill puzzle game. No stress, multiple solutions, cute albeit pesky cat that pops in and doots stuff around with his paws just to mess with you antagonist-style. What I got was...not really that. And I was not only disappointed, I was actually pretty angry. I got this game on sale and I still think I paid too much.

The puzzles start off fun. They scratch that particular "everything in its place" itch, as so many others have said. But the game quickly devolves into, "Wait, what the hell am I supposed to be doing?" So many of the puzzles have just a single solution, and SO many of those solutions are so utterly convoluted and/or arbitrary that it became incredibly frustrating. And by the time I've clicked around enough to finally figure it out, the puzzle gets ripped away from me before I can properly observe/glean satisfaction from what I did. Worst of all was the Polaroid puzzle. An online walkthrough I looked at literally said, "This is the solution. I don't know why." What kind of game design is that? And what's more, THE CAT IS BARELY THERE. Do not promise an autistic lady a cat and then cheap out! >:(

I also agree with another user who commented that the end sequence went on for an absurd amount of time. Like...absurd absurd.

It's a very cute concept, but some of the puzzles can be very frustrating because if anything is even slightly out of place, it's incorrect. So you end up spending a lot of time meticulously moving each piece over a tiny bit until it's finally good enough. I thought this game would be nice and relaxing for my OCD but it was actually the opposite. If you just want cute, challenging organisational puzzles, then this game is perfect, but I seriously would not recommend if you have OCD.

As time goes on Iâ€™ve learned to appreciate engaging casual games that donâ€™t require intense focus. Small adventure games that only take a few hours to beat, relaxing puzzle games that donâ€™t really have an ending, and anything in between are fun to enjoy and veg out on. Itâ€™s the same effect for me as binge-watching a show. A Little to the Left tries to be that. It has engaging puzzles and serotonin-squirting organization puzzles along with cute visuals, but it does come with issues.


The gameâ€™s puzzles start out fairly simple. There are around 75 puzzles in the main game with 365 daily puzzles. Puzzles start out with just straightening photos on a wall, putting cat toys in a basket, arranging a dinner set, aligning colored pencils in a certain order, stacking rugs, etc. These first dozen puzzles are relaxing and really give you a taste of what this game could be. Yes, I said could be as the game quickly ramps up the abstractness, and even with a full-on guide and accessible hint system in the game it still doesnâ€™t make sense. The arrangement puzzles are the absolute worst. These are abstract shapes that donâ€™t snap together but instead are arranged in a specific pattern. The patterns usually make no sense since the pieces are so far apart. These puzzles will frustrate most players and lead you into a false sense of relaxation and simple organization and stacking.

Thatâ€™s not to say I donâ€™t like a challenge. One puzzle has you sliding a mirror to the left and right and arranging the objects according to the reflection. Another has you stacking cat food cans in colored columns that match. These puzzles were enjoyable. My favorite was the organization puzzles. Put all the junk in the correct cubbies. Thatâ€™s a lot of fun with the process of elimination. Sadly, there are only about four of those puzzles and I wanted more. The difficulty is all over the place, but itâ€™s the artificial difficulty. The puzzles are just so obscure sometimes that most people may quit the game.


I also found the snapping system pretty broken. Sometimes you place an object in the right spot and it will snap into place and make a faint ding sound. However, abstract pattern puzzles require two symmetrical objects in the same spot in the scene before they will snap into place. This hinders progress as there are no tactile hints that you are making progress. There is a hint system that shows you the solution by erasing and uncovering. This was nice as I would try to just erase one part and still be able to solve the rest on my own. However, even the hints sometimes make zero sense.

Thankfully, you can still move on with the â€œLet It Beâ€ system that skips the puzzle for you. There are some puzzles that have two or more solutions such as sorting from highest to shortest, then by color, and then by matching an image on the same object. While the first solution may seem easy to spot the additional solutions can be insanely abstract and obscure. I really tried to solve as many as I could on my own, but in the end, I solved maybe a quarter of the puzzles by myself. There were just too many that were frustrating or I felt I wasnâ€™t making any progress. Some were just me overthinking the puzzle, but some were just poorly designed.


The visuals are cute. It has a pastel minimalistic look. Lots of colored pencils, charcoal, and watercolor art designs. The music is great and relaxing to listen to in the background itâ€™s just too bad the game isnâ€™t as relaxing. In the end, A Little to the Left is misleading in its first dozen puzzles and quickly ramps up the abstractness and obscurity too much requiring too many puzzles to be skipped. The most enjoyable ones are too few. This isnâ€™t a bad game at all. There are fun puzzles peppered throughout the bad ones, and the overall cat aesthetic is enjoyable with great music.

PROS: If you like cozy, single-player games with a tiny puzzle element, this is your game. 

CONS: I do not recommend it for the color blind as some options are close in color (blue/grey, red/green) and there is no option for changing those. There are no instructions whatsoever. There are walk-throughs online, but otherwise you just have to figure it all out on your own. There's no time limits, though. 

DEVS: Include some instruction options. Some puzzles were difficult to figure out what was needed. The spider web, the piles of paper, the broken crockery with loops on it, specifically. Some could be looked up online, but I just wanted to know what the rule was, not what the solution was.  All games should come with a color slider option for the various kinds of color-blind people.

If you get obsessive with games and can't put them down, this will last you one night, maybe two. If you are able to limit yourself, it could be fun over the course of a few weeks, maybe. The levels are quick and satisfying if you can spot patterns quickly, but there are a few trickier ones that are really nice to put your mind into, particularly the tool shelf level. I really enjoyed this game!

This is a wonderful game, I enjoyed streaming it very much. Cozy and comedic. Only thing I would add is a tutorial. If I had not seen others play this game first I would have been very confused on what to do and what the star system meant after finding one of the puzzle solutions. Very creative and fun.

This game sratches my brain good

I think this game is really cute, and well made. I love the levels where there are multiple solutions.

The two biggest flaws is the price, which might be a bit high for the hours for some people. And the fact there are multiple achievements to log in and do the Daily. But the daily is a level that'll take you 10 seconds at most.

It's going to take me 2-3 months to get 100% achievements on this game and that's frankly ridiculous.

I sure do love my animals. This game made me realize how even though my animals frustrate me sometimes, especially while trying to keep a tidy home, I love them unconditionally - - all the way to the moon and back. 

This is a fantastic game for anyone who likes to fixate on things and maybe thinks they're a weirdo. The daily cleaning mini-games will become a ritual for me before going to work or doing homework. Exercises like this get my brain in the right mood and focused. It's also amusing to play while sharing your screen with a friend, so you can share how weird you are about how you organize or solve puzzles. The art style and music are phenomenal. There are a couple of levels where some of the noises of the puzzles are a bit grating, but other than that; I had a fantastic time playing through it.
buy it. pussy

This is definitly not a game for everyone and you probably need to be in a specific state of mind while you play it. Some levels are honestly infuriating but most are fairly straightforward, there are a few puzzles, especially in the last chapter, but most is just figuring out in what different ways you can sort the objects or make patterns. If you would like it or not, can probably be answered in one single question, - Do you organize your stuff at home in specific patterns. If your awnser is "Well yeah, obviously. Who doesn't!", then pick this up, However if you awnser is - "No, what kind of question is that, why would I do something like that", then no, you will hate this game. 

Me? Yeah i'm in camp A, so I did enjoy this game for the most part, but I do think the last couple of levels where kind of terrible to be honest. Especially the last one, it goes on forever to the point that you start to wonder if you are doing something wrong.

It's a good game, but rather short.  I enjoyed most of it, but there were some issues that bothered me, and maybe worth considering by those wanting to buy it.  The biggest problem I had was that the puzzles don't have any introduction as to what you have to do to solve them.  On many puzzles, this is the biggest challenge.  Once you figure it out, the solution is trivial.  I am not fond of this genre.  I like a challenging puzzle where the rules are given to you and you spend your time applying them to solve the puzzle.  Anyway, there is a hint system, which can unstick you and there is also a "let it be" button to skip. I used both.  In a few cases, as far as I could tell, the puzzle was solved , but it wouldn't move on, so I used the latter button. Despite my annoyance with some aspects, I still recommend it heartily.
yes

A very calming, cute, satisfying game. You'll finish it very quickly, so keep that in mind. I'm really glad they have the "daily tidy" function. Keeps me coming back. I'm hoping they'll add even more to it later but I'm very happy that I purchased it. :-)

This game is great if you love puzzle games. Some of the puzzles are harder to figure out than others, of course, and the game offers a hint system. There are daily puzzles, the Daily Tidy's. The art style is really cute. It's a very relaxed and relaxing game even when a cat starts swiping at your neatly placed items. Would recommend.

With all my love... get this when it is on sale.

this game is charming, beautiful, and calming, and i love that there's more than one way to do things. i would say that the developers could afford to be more imaginative in the approach to some puzzles (in the symmetry puzzles for instance), but overall it's very pretty and i loved spending time with this game.

I came to this game because of its beautiful visuals and because I love to organize, and I expected to have a wholesome and calming experience but rather my time playing this game filled me with frustration :(
The levels are so picky in the way that *they* want the items to be placed even if they are organized perfectly in my eyes. I just wish there was more room for creativity and diversity in the way you choose to organize and place your items. The game "unpacking" has this quality of giving the player leeway to organize in their own style and it does it well.
Also some of the levels were quite vague and not intuitive in how the items are supposed to be moved which added to my frustration.
Anyway, I didn't enjoy this game, but I have seen plenty of other reviews that did so play if you want, but personally I wouldn't recommend it to my friends.
I love the puzzles! Can be a little difficult but I just walk away and come back and usually am able to figure it out.
my ocd senses are tingling

My favourite puzzle game to date.  I love how hands off this game is in terms of instructions and tutorial, makes it a much more in depth game than your standard puzzle game. You have to come up with your own rules based on observations and that makes this seemingly simple game a more immersive one. I recommend this game for everyone, especially if you have trouble with translating big picture ideas into small details or vice versa. It will exercise your "out of the box" thinking and logic skills. I blasted through this game in a few hours because I was enjoying it so much. Also very satisfying. It drives me crazy when I can see multiple solutions to a puzzle but the game only lets you input a specific solution as the only one but this game encourages you to go back and do them all, which scratches the reward centre of my brain.

Its actually impressive, some of the levels and the extra stars are actually hard to get and the sounds are really really satisfying and the music is really good. I got sucked in the first couple of hours I played and couldn't put it down. There's a LOT of levels so you can play this game for hours on end til your hearts content. 10/10 defiantly would recommend for anyone who likes sorting or just likes relaxing games.

I'd definitely recommend if you enjoy games that are cozy, cute, or are puzzles, because this has them all! i still can't get over the sound affects because they are just so satisfying to listen to<3333

Great game if you want a more relaxing but mentally stimulating puzzle game. I played this whilst recovering after a hospital stay and I've really enjoyed it. The developers also added a cool themed task event for Easter, which would be great to see for other seasons and holidays. Also, it has a cute animated cat in it. You can't really go wrong :)

Quite cute, fun gameplay, some confusing challenges, but overall very good

This was a game that I had happened to find on a video through Youtube Shorts, and I thought it had been interesting.  I love to organize, and it seemed like a creative game!  It didn't take long for me to figure out what game this was and purchased it.  

The game itself has a cute little hand-drawn charm to it which is what also drew me in, the puzzles soon captivating me.  Each puzzle was unique with a few different repeats, and there were even a couple puzzles that had a few different ways of solving them!  I really enjoyed how much it got my brain to thinking about different matches.  Every chapter was also different too, like the food-themed one, or the workbench chapter.  There were always items I didn't think really belonged in a couple items, but to be honest, everyone has some sort of random junk in their drawers on occasion.  The Special events for the Daily Tidy was also a cute little addition and I loved how different those were!  It brought in some of the knowledge you gained from previous puzzles, but also brought in new ways of solving things.

The music was soothing, though it did get a tiny bit monotonous towards the end of my achievement hunting.  The only time I remember the music changing was towards the end.  Personally, I think it adds to the relaxing atmosphere and can't think of anything else that could be played while you go through the puzzles. 

I just wish that the hints for the puzzles were a little better about explaining what needed to be done.   Erasing the lines to reveal the hints were cute, but I struggled with learning what to do with some of the puzzles we were given.  However, this is a tiny issue in comparison to all the good things the game does.

I personally enjoyed this game a lot and definitely recommend it to anyone that enjoys organizing or just needs to kill a little bit of time~  Definitely worth the purchase!
Short but sweet and extremely satisfying game
a wonderful cozy game - very relaxing!

Finally a game where I can unleash the full power of my OCD

This is a wholesome, fun and relaxing game to play. Whilst it can somewhat scratch that aligned perfection OCD itch, remember this is a puzzle game with huge variety, so don't come in with that expectation. There actually are multiple solutions to a puzzle, with better solutions granting higher stars. This is both impressive and shocking, because it's very rare to have truly differentiating solutions. The visuals are aesthetic and pleasing to the eyes; you can play after finishing work, and replay levels to try figure out those other solutions. My only wish is that they add more content in the form of DLC. Although there are plentiful and sufficient number of puzzles, you can't but hope for more. There are daily puzzles, which are variations of existing ones, but that isn't exactly what I was looking for. This is an immensely satisfying game, and worth every penny.

very nice and relaxing, but maybe a bit short for the price. The soundtrack is amazing, and the puzzles are nice, but usually not very difficult. In the case you do get stuck on a puzzle, you can easily look at a hint, which is basically just the solution to the puzzle but behind scribbles you have to erase, so you can give yourself the whole solution or just a piece depending on what you want. It's also trivial to skip a puzzle instead if you'd prefer to come back to it later and solve it without a hint. The "daily tidy" feature is kinda, eh, as it's mostly just slightly changed versions of puzzles from the main game, that repeat after a while, but it's still kinda nice. And occasionally there's some holiday themed new-ish puzzles.

Overall, I'd say it's a great game, though maybe wait for a sale if you prefer more of a bang for your buck, as it's not too long.

The game was pretty pleasant and the art style is very cute. I went into this game thinking it would be a fairly zen-like experience focused on organizing and putting things away (a la Unpacking); however, it really is a puzzle game, which I was totally fine with. I felt as through there were a handful of puzzles where I just sat there staring with absolutely NO clue what the theme of the puzzle was. There were multiple puzzles that, when you look them up, just wanted you to organize the stuff in the way that just seemed aesthetically pleasing to the creators, with no real connection to the locations of the items. On the other hand, the majority were very interesting, unique, and clever puzzles. I'd say, over all, there were maybe 10 extremely frustrating "puzzles" to the 70-something scenes you work through. Despite the frustration with the few "puzzles", I'd say its definitely worth a play through!
