As a colourblind player I feel let down. 

The game itself is very fun and relaxing. The puzzles are short, but clever. The art style is cute and cosy. The game has literally everything going for it. Well, until you get to the levels where you need to sort things by colour, after which the puzzles become literally impossible due to the earlier mentioned art style. At least for a player like me.

My level of colourblindness isn't even all that intense, so I can only imagine how bad it is for someone with an even more sever case!

I get going for a soft muted pastel adjacent colour scheme, but if you're going to do that knowing players will sort things by colour, the very least you could do is add a colourblindness setting in the menu. That feature has become quite standard in gaming and would not be hard to implement. Either that, or make things that you sort by colour more distinct via hue, saturation, intensity etc.

Again, the levels are short and easy, so it's not a game ending road block. You can just brute force a solution eventually. That being said, it does really ruin what is supposed to be a fun and relaxing experience.

I know the game has been out for a little bit now, but I still hope this'll be addressed at some point in the future in some way.

This cute small organisation game is a lot of fun and whilst simple is extremely satisfying. The goal is to complete a series of puzzles which are different imperfect scenarios which need to be cleaned. The annoying cat really gets in the way and adds very little to the game but it does add an extra aspect to pay attention to. The game isn't easy to play over and over as the extra daily puzzles are identical to the main puzzles and don't offer anything extra. Overall though this is a good game and is worth the play through.

Frustratingly annoying with really annoying wiggling graphics. This game will drive you absolutely bonkers and leave you screaming at the developers wondering why they think telepathy is part good part of game play! There's often no guidance on what to do...no clues...just a pile of mess to move into a different pile of mess.

The wiggling graphics is no joke. When you're trying to stare at a puzzle to find a solution, the graphics keep moving and jittering all over the place. I found an option to turn off "shaking", but apparently this didn't fix this graphics annoyance. (I still have no clue what "shaking" was removed when I turned it off).

The menus are equally annoying in this game. The cursor changes randomly from a 4 fingers out hand to a pointing finger. Clicking objects is a gamble on if you've hit the magical hitbox. Also, why do I have to click 3 times to get to the daily task? Why isn't this just one click? I clicked "daily task"....so that's what I want. Why do I have to click 2 more times on pointless menus?

Poorly designed, strange interface, and puzzles that require mind-melding with the programmers. Skip this one...not worth it.

(Even the music sometimes gets annoying...and I have it down set to 10%).

A Little to the Left is a great game if you enjoy sorting/organizing. I found the art style charming and the troublesome cat delightful. However, the game does have some flaws I want to acknowledge. Firstly, the further you get into the game, the more puzzles you will see that don't fit the motif of the others. There are a lot of puzzles that don't involve organizing, or in some cases there are puzzles that require you to deliberately un-organize something. 
There are also a lot of puzzles in which the solution is very un-intuitive. I found myself getting frustrated at a couple of them because, rather than being challenging in a way that makes you think, I could not fathom how I was supposed to figure something out on my own. There are a lot of puzzles that could benefit from a bit of an explanation. There is a hints system within the game, but I did not discover its existence until i was in the second to last chapter of the game. The hints are also somewhat inconsistent. Some of the hints completely gave away the solution, while others didn't tell me anything that wasn't immediately obvious. The puzzle I had the most trouble with was [spoiler] the one where you pet the cat. I ended up having to look this one up because I thought the cat's upset was based on where I pet it depending on color, and the hint was no help. I think the changing colors in this puzzle caused an added layer of confusion due to me thinking they were important to what I was doing. I also had trouble with the tupperware-stacking level. There didn't appear to be any reason as to why some combinations worked and some did not. [/spoiler] 
I only bring these issues up so the developers may keep them in mind for the future, not to dissuade anyone from playing this game. There is a lot more to enjoy about this game, and the issues weren't too prevalent and could mostly be overlooked.  
A great aspect of this game is that many levels have several solutions. This is a great way to accommodate different players ways of thinking, and provides a fun challenge for completitionists to see things from a new perspective. The only complication with this mechanic is that you can only view which levels have multiple solutions either by completing the level, or viewing it from the levels menu. The game usually goes from one level to the next, so most players likely won't visit the level method too often. There were a couple puzzles (for example, the box stacking level) where I was trying to accomplish two solutions at once because I did not realize they were separate solutions. I think the game could benefit by displaying the solution number to the player at the start of the level.
Overall, I think this is a great game a lot of people will enjoy. My criticisms come from a place of appreciation. I recommend giving this game a shot!

This is the type of game I adore.  I have played Unpacking, a similar game, on three different systems because I like them so much.  I was hoping this game would give me a similar experience, of satisfying puzzle solving and a cute environment.  While it delivers in the environment, sound design, and visuals, the game itself feels unpolished in a way that I felt I needed to review.  While most of the puzzles are solvable with some patience, others require a near pixel-perfect adjustment or clicking to get the game to recognize the solution.  The hint system is helpful at times and completely unhelpful in others.  In the [spoiler] star levels, [/spoiler] one of the hints is for a completely different, previous puzzle.  I have dyscalculia, and relied on the hints in several levels because of it, and when the hints were broken or the game would not recognize the correct solution, it led to immense frustration.  I streamed the game to my partner as I played, and they shared my frustration - being unable to tell if you are doing the puzzle wrong or the game is bugging does not make for a relaxing puzzle solving experience.  Were these kinks worked out, I would have loved the game.  As it stands, I cannot recommend it, and I say that with great disappointment.
Adored this game!!! What a fun way to get the brain working. The illustrations are adorable and the style is immaculate.

I am sad to leave a poor review of this game.  Conceptually, it's very cute, and I greatly enjoyed the majority of it.  I have two grievances.
One is that it felt like there was a tangible decline in the puzzle quality as the game went on.  There was an acceptable amount of redundancy, I would say - although you can only straighten photos or sort junk drawers so many times before the novelty wears off - but some of the puzzles were genuinely frustrating.  A few of them made no sense to me and required hints and I have no idea how anyone would have ever figured them out without them; there were also a few instances where I just clicked around randomly to find interactions with items that were not at all obvious and I don't feel like that's good design.  The frustrations I started to feel in the second half of the game took a lot away from the enjoyment I got out of the first half.
My second issue - the larger one - was playtime/content.  Even with the struggles I had, I completed the base game in 3 hours.  I am glad I bought this on sale, but still don't feel it was particularly good value for the money.

I really really wanted to like this game. The graphics and art are super cute and nice. Though I found the puzzles to be very unintuitive and boring. i found that most of the puzzles barely made sense even after checking the hints and the ones that did make sense were very unsatisfying and anticlimactic. And fwiw im typically someone who avoids hints and guides up until the very last moment when i am really 100% stumped, i enjoy working out even the toughest puzzles on my own. I kept waiting for the puzzles to get better or for there to be some sort of story along with it but sadly neither happened. The puzzles were too boring or illogical for there to be no story, it needed serious compensation. The puzzles that didn't make sense even after the hints really felt like the devs just chose random placements for things and then stuck with it. if you didnt get the exact pattern right, the puzzle wouldnt be solved, even if there was no rhyme or reason to the "pattern". I found myself just copying the hints like i was copying someones science homework without actually studying it myself lol. it sucked. honestly, if you want a good satisfying puzzle/organizing game, just play Unpacking or Assembled With Care. Gorgeous, simple and satisfying (most of the times). There are some really good and relaxing levels and some where I had no idea what to do and I wanted to pull my hair out, which is the opposite of the game's intention I think, and that is where the game suffers the most. The levels where you have to organize stuff are the best in my opinion and there's not enough of them.

UX isn't the best either with an abundance of animations that block any player interaction, like when alt tabbing the game goes straight to the pause menu, which takes a couple of seconds of animation to do. Or when going to the level selection menu the game scrolls very slowly through every level you have passed and you cannot do anything until it finishes.

There's little to no story and no connection between the puzzles/chapters. There are some great ideas here, but I don't think the game exploited its full potential. I think a sequel could very much improve on the existing grounds and make it better, but right now, I don't think I would recommend.
An excellent satisfying puzzle game

What sets A Little to the Left apart from other puzzle games is its intuitive and playful design. The game's charming illustrations and surprising scenarios add to the overall appeal of the game. Whether you're trying to figure out which way the clock hands should point or how to arrange the eggs just right, there's always a new challenge waiting for you in A Little to the Left. One of the most delightful aspects of the game is the mischievous cat who likes to shake things up.

But perhaps the best feature of the game is its accessibility. If you donâ€™t like the puzzle or you are completely stuck you can simply skip it without any harm to progression. But if you still want to finish the puzzle, you can get as much hint as you desire with the gameâ€™s awesome hint system where you can erase a sketch of the puzzle gradually to figure out what to do. And finally, the game has no time limits or jumping puzzles which all in all makes it a perfect game for gamers such as myself!

Overall, A Little to the Left is a must-play for puzzle game fans and anyone who enjoys the satisfaction of a well-organized space ðŸ˜„

A good example is the level with the balls in the paintings. literally didn't do anything different it just suddenly worked after I looked it up, I hate that level so much.

Other than all that this game is great and I'd fully recommend it to people (at least the first four chapters, the fifth one is kinda weak in comparison and... just not really fun). I'd especially recommend it if you're a neat freak or have some amount of OCD (Which I'm sure I probably do) as then the way the game thinks just sorta makes sense and you're likely to see the solutions pretty quickly (except in the fifth chapter, it sucks).

in certain puzzles it wants you to arrange jars depending on how the cartoon liquid is flowing, to make a full wave. yet it constantly doesn't accept very basic patterns as the 'right' pattern

combine that with the fact that some puzzles have multiple ways to solve them (great) but no quick way of actually accesing the puzzle again (bad).
 every time you complete a level and want to go back to do the other pattern. you have to wait for the next puzzle to load. press escape. go to the level menu and wait for the slideshow animation where it checks off all the levels you completed since last time you were in the level select menu. wait for the level you completed to load solve it. then wait for the next level to load a second time.

A short simple game about tidyin and organising a home, while a mischievious  cat saunters about. 
There is no text or dialogue during the levels, but the game still manages to tell an engaging story about the futillity of obsessive organising. The tone is lighthearted and whimsical, but as someone who personal experince with OCD, it actually hit me a little harder, than was perhaps intended.

The game is equal parts relaxing and stressfull, depending on wether you just finished a level or is trying to figure out what the game wants you to do. The challenge with playing a game with no text is, that you have to figure out what the developer wants you to do in every single level. There is no straight up moonlogic and the hint system is usually very helpful, but I did have to google one level to figure out how to do, what I was trying to do. Many of the levels have more than one solution and they all allow you to skip them, if you are stuck. Mostly the game is never so frustrating, that it lessens the satisfaction from sorting the items just right and there are a lot of items to sort

If you are really debating on buying the game and want to know if its worth it- its not worth 15 bucks, I will be honest. The game has nothing necessarily bad going for it, but don't let the 75+ levels fool you like it fooled me. In total, there are 80 actual levels you can do, and some have different solutions to them. Though I would say that some of the levels are wayyyy too easy, and some are way too hard. It goes from organizing 5 colored pencils in the order of a rainbow in 5 seconds, to hanging up different tools on a wall based on where the nails are which took me like 15 minutes to figure out. Its about 2-3 hours of gameplay. With little repeatability. 

The game can genuinely be more picky on how to organize things than you would think. I personally think it would be way better if you reorganized everything in the way you wanted, and then said you were finished with the level, and continue to the next. Then at the end it could show you all the before and afters, and you get that feeling of having cleaned or fixed the mess to your liking, and not having to do it the way the game wanted you to. Maybe like an alternate game mode like that, idk. 

The art style and sound are really really nice though, I am personally a huge fan of all the little noises it plays when you interact with all the different items on all the levels. I like the sound of satisfying noises so if you are the same then this game definitely is nice in that field. 

Also the daily tidy thing is nice, but it just chooses a random level for you to do, so you are just repeating a level you've already done if you beat the game. So they take like 5 seconds to do. 

I would say this game is much more like a 5/10 dollar game as is, but I do think the devs plan to add more levels in the future, which is cool. Game itself is fun though, and a good 75-80% of the levels are satisfying to complete.

A relaxing game that any organised individual will love. If you enjoy keeping things neat and tidy then this is the game for you.

The music helps create a calming atmosphere and the art style is simple yet cute. Definitely a must have for those who play games to switch off their brain and just have fun.

This game is neat, although it's a bit too full of itself for my own liking. A lot of the puzzles are fun to solve and figure out the rules, while others feel cheap. The fact that some puzzles have multiple solutions is really neat, but it feels like a punch in the gut that those extra solutions don't have any hints. And also that the hint for every puzzle is justâ€¦ revealing the solution, rather than being an actual hint.

It also has the *worst* toggle-hold setting of any game I've ever played, where it seems to be the least-effort implementation. There are lots of points where your hold can be "dropped" while moving objects in certain ways, and for the ordinary hold setting this is fine since you need to let go and re-click to grab again, but the toggle-hold requires you to click twice. Or, in some cases, something that only requires a simple tap requires clicking twice. It made this game unnecessarily frustrating at times.

The game definitely overdoes achievements by giving achievements for using hints, for not using hints, for skipping levels, for not skipping levels. And some weird obscure achievements that just feel like filler. I know a lot of people don't really care for achievements, but I like using them as a form of completion, and this game really spits in the face of that.

And finallyâ€¦ the daily tidy is a neat feature until you realise that it's just randomly reskinned versions of existing levels. It would be fun if the daily tidy only used levels you've already completed, or if you could complete levels via the daily tidy, but that's not how it works. It would have been nice to see parity for this, but since it's just an extra feature, I won't hold it against the game. I've had *some* fun with it.

Overallâ€¦ I would give this game an extremely positive review and a solid recommend if it weren't for the stuff I mentioned. Since steam forces a positive or negative review, I'll skew toward positive, but it's not nearly what I hoped for.

A Little to the Left is an uncomfortable puzzle game. The premise is light and arty and fun: you are tidying up and also there is a cat that sometimes messes up your tidying, so figure out the organization logic of each level and earn a bit of satisfaction from imposing order upon chaos. It's fairly polished little package of riddles, but it really depends on your opinions on cats and on the real life activity that this is a video game version of.

Basically, I think it suffers from too many issues to be all that fun. The basic interaction loop, of dragging a thing around and seeing what happens to it, behaves quite oddly sometimes, for instance refusing to grab a particular object or dragging it an inconsistent rate. The systems that detect when an element is close enough to solved to adjust it into place, are a little too eager to interfere. The riddles oscillate between too simple and irritatingly large but have a lot of trouble hitting the sweet spot. There's a theme of like, celebrating cats, I guess, that didn't really land for me. It kinda felt like cleaning up someone else's house while they talked about their cat, which might be your bag but it ain't mine.

I find this to be a disappointing game overall. Not because it didn't try its best, but because it demonstrated that its premise is just undeliverable. There's too much bespoke logic and assets and creativity that needs to go into each level of this game, for how quickly the player can breeze through it and how attentive the designer needs to be to possible player solutions. Both failure modes of the level design---the player finding an arrangement the designer didn't recognize as a solution, and the player accidentally falling into a solution that they didn't even notice---feel more bad than a success feels good, I think. And the daily puzzle mode serves campaign puzzles with some of the elements randomized, which for me is too similar to the campaign; the prospect of playing that every day for a hundred days, in order to get a little badge and a cheevo, is kind of insulting.

A Little to the Left is a nice, relaxed puzzle game. There's no pressure from a timer or any other reason to rush, and that's good. Because honestly some of the puzzles are downright un-intuitive.

I found I either needed to use a hint, or mess with stuff for a good while on a level before something "clicked" and I suddenly got what I needed to do.

The game has a good number of Steam achievements, providing decent replay value. But added replay value comes from the Tidy of the Day, which is a nice way to not have to engage the story, but still take on a quick puzzle.

I recommend A Little to the Left, as a relaxed but challenging puzzle game with a cute story and relatable premise.

Honestly I would not recommand this game. 
At first it looks like a neat game, to please the OCD within, but as you proceed the limits of the game become painfully obvious. This game shares a lot of the problems, the puzzel-solving genre is known for (like there beeing only the answers, the game developers thought of).
(Which is a real problem in this game, as everybody prefers a different style of sorting things. (By god, I would not put things away like the developers would.))

Apart from this problem, the controls left me confused from time to time aswell. As realistic as they are, I'd just wish they were handled differntly. You are left to drag pieces around the screen, searching for the approved spot quite often. 
At other times your answers seem correct (even matching up with the ones in the hint), but you still won't get the pass, because of a can beeing (not even) an inch away from the place it should be. 

The "leave it" option is a way to combat this, but it always leaves a bitter taste in ones mouth, when used.

There are way better games - in this genre - to spend your time and money on than this one.

I bought it when it was on sale and still think it was a little expensive considering what you get. Finished the game including all solutions and daily tidy in a couple of hours and since I now know the solutions it will be quite awhile until I can enjoy it again. I did however try, and it wasn't nearly as fun.

On the plus side the game perfectly balances chill and cozy with a little challenge on a few levels. Most of the levels are a breeze but highly satisfying and once in awhile they'll give you a little brain teaser.

Review from someone with ADHD:

the positives: it looks cute. 

the negatives: I played 5 min of this the refunded. Why would this game ever be $14.99? It's like if they took House Flipper, cut all of the graphics out of it, and then just gave up puzzle variation. This should be an app game for $5.00 bucks, that would make sense. But $14.99 for what, 75+ puzzles of just organizing things? What in the hell is that? 

I'm sure this was truly relaxing for some people but oh my god to me it was just anxiety producing seeing these mismatched items and then putting them in ways that felt, clunky and bad. If I wanted to clean things, I'd pay 2.50 for a ticket back on the train and clean my room, why is this a game? At least in House Flipper you have like, a house to complete, so you can see how it's changing over time, and you get excited about the next power washer section, stuff like that. 

You know what this made me feel like? It made me feel like I was drinking boba with the tapioca at the bottom, and you have to get all the tapioca balls in the straw or you feel anxious. At least I do. But in this case you solve it, and then you just jump to getting more of a mess! There's no "look at all these fixed things you did" it's just, hey you are anxious about this messed up area, you put things either next to or onto things, then you get a star and then go to the next mess. Don't play this game. Please. And if you have ADHD, man I hope you can enjoy this, but this game at this price just made me reallly annoyed. If this was $5.00 this review would not have been as harsh.

The art is really charming and I like the puzzle design. I get tired after doing a puzzle or two and so I only play for a few minutes a day at most, but I feel like that's how this game is best played. It made me sad to see so many people complain about the price; I feel like it's well worth full price for an entirely hand drawn indie game that's very unique and whimsical. The creators did an amazing job.

I hate to give this game a negative review--this is another case where I wish Steam had a "meh" button in addition to thumbs up/down.

When I heard about this game, I was very excited to play it. I've always been obsessive about organizing stuff, so it sounded perfect for me. But somehow...this just isn't quite it.

My number one issue with the game is actually the setting. It seems to take place in some Martha Stewart dreamscape: nothing but houseplants, seashells, pretty rocks, and household objects. Weirdly enough, there is basically zero overlap between the things I actually like to organize in real life and the things I get to organize in this game. There's no level where you re-indent all your code, or where you get to redo the cable management behind the TV, or where you have to guess what screw goes in what hole as you put a smartphone back together. So I really couldn't relate to the overall scenario that much.

Another issue is how boring most of the puzzles are. The solution to half the puzzles is just to sort by color. And if not that, then just sort by size, or make the shapes fit with each other. There are only a few really tricky puzzles that call for any lateral thinking at all. A handful of the levels don't even have a single, correct solution; you just have to [spoiler] make a freeform symmetrical arrangement out of some random stuff[/spoiler]. It's more of an color-acuity test than real puzzler.

I was also let down by the level of interactivity. You can click and drag to rearrange stuff on the screen--and that's it. You can't attach parts together, break things, fold things, turn parts over, etc. So most of the mechanical, kinesthetic joy that comes from disassembling or fixing stuff is lost. It especially stings in the tool-themed chapter; you get a screen full of bolts, nuts, and wrenches, but can you put the nuts on the bolts, maybe using the wrenches? Nope. They get organized in some sort of cafeteria tray, same as the seashells and paperclips from before.

I was also unimpressed with the audio. The music is very repetitive and not very good. There is one track with this one arpeggiated piano chord, and it just goes up the scale, down the scale, up the scale, down the scale...I had to put the game on mute when I came back to replay the levels for 100% completion. The sound effects for picking up and moving objects around are also much too loud; the effect is often pretty jarring. If you move stuff around too fast, it turns into some kind of extreme ASMR.

And there are some other careless details besides all that. For instance, many levels have more than one solution. After finding one solution, I always wanted to try to get the others (sometimes they are painfully obvious). But the game automatically boots you off to the next level, so you have to exit to the level select and pick out the level the hard way. Another example is the daily puzzles; I think they are automatically generated from maybe 5 or 10 possible templates. The solutions are the same every time, so after a couple repetitions you can solve them on sight. Not sure how this is supposed to retain my interest.

Still, there are a few things I liked about the game. The narrative with the cat is a cute way to tie the different chapters together, and there are a couple of memorable puzzles in the mix. The art style is consistent and fits with the rest of the game, and it's a nice, focused experience. I can't deny that it held my attention for long enough to finish the game and do some achievement-hunting (the devs promise that the broken ones will be fixed in the next update). I'm sure some people will like this game much more than I did.

In general, I very much enjoyed this game. I found many of the puzzles to be quite clever, if a bit obtuse at first. I appreciated the multiple possible solutions for each puzzle. And I, for one, actually really appreciated how no puzzle actually has a stated end goal within itself. It is just presented and you have to figure out what you are even attempting to do, which I think is really the puzzle at its core.

I think my one gripe with the game, outside of its length vs. cost, is the fact that the difficulty of the puzzles doesn't seem to progress in a logical sense. A lot of the earlier puzzles are easier ones, but you will occasionally run into one that is leagues harder than the previous few, and you will wonder where this difficulty came from. And yes, even though there are chapters, the puzzles within each chapter don't even follow a difficulty progression. This could be just the way I looked at the puzzles and your experience with them may differ ever so slightly, though.

That being said, I enjoyed the trickier puzzles and only wish there were more of them.

And the story? Well, in theory, there is one. But the weird, trippy ending kind of proves that there actually really isn't one. At all. So, what have i taken from this game?   C A T .  B E C O M E   C A T

A little to the left is a cozy game, which is perfect for people who like satisfying games or moments irl. 
Let me make this quite (not) short with my personal opinion.
Positive: 
-a nice cozy games with different kind of levels - almost no level is the same or similar, many different things to do 
-Worth more than 3 hours of gameplay till you finished it and even then you can still play it again to try out different methods on how to play that level (the stars seem to indicate how many possible outcomes there are)
-it's a very cute game, I like the music as well - made with lots of love!

Negative imo:
-Some level are the kind of cozy I expected when I got the game and saw the demo last year summer or something - but some levels are just "too crazy". I like a good challenge and I like to think on how to do stuff, but some levels were just horrible. Even with hints I did not understand some of them. 
-I got very angry when I did not understand the logic behind some of the levels and even with hints could not "play" them. Trust me, I know that you can't do a game where everyone can do freely what they want in a gameplay like here, but for some levels I was just so frustrated to the point that I did not enjoy it anymore. 

So, I know that "cozy" games are probably not my kind of game, but I still like to think that one day there will be one cozy game that will make me really relaxed and cozy, but this was not it - sadly. 
It frustrated me so much, one time I literally could not take it anymore and was almost giving up on it, but then I decided that I will at least play it fully. Look at every level and see what the end of it brings me. The end - a whole 'nother story. Some levels were just too difficult for me to really relax. 

But please. Give this game a chance if you think that it will have a chance to make you cozy, because it is the perfect game for most people! :) Very well done (just nothing for me)

I bought this game primarily to play on my steam deck and I have been thoroughly enjoying it since purchasing it. A quick note to those who want to go after the achievements quickly, it is going to take a full year to get them all playing daily, so if that is something you donâ€™t want to do then pass this over. But the point of this game is for players to pass the time in a nice relaxing manner with no rush to solve them in a timely manner and no penalty for failure either. In fact you can go through the whole game without solving everything and still get to the credits. And each level has hints where you could slowly expose what is needed to figure out if youâ€™re on the right track or not. The â€œcampaignâ€ is about 3 hours long and every day you get a new puzzle which is just a different variation of the â€œcampaignâ€ puzzles. The only thing I would probably change is maybe the pricing, maybe down to $10 USD, but thatâ€™s just me. Regardless, Iâ€™m looking forward to whatever the next game this small studio will come out with next, and be kind to the developers. This seems to be their first game that theyâ€™ve made.

I love the idea of the game, the graphics, the music, but I find some of the riddles incredibly frustrating. Sometimes, I had to move one tiny item around my screen for multiple minutes, trying to hit just the right spot for it. For multiple riddles, I had to open a walkthrough, just so I could see how others solved it... and despite having everything (seemingly) the same as them, my solution wouldn't work. I wish I loved this game and I do love the first few levels, but after that it became just a chore and I am definitely less relaxed than I was when I started playing.

I wanted so badly to like this game, but I have to agree with other negative reviewers - a lot of the puzzles skew towards 'frustrating and arbitrary' rather than 'thought-provoking and satisfying'. It scratched that itch so well at first with the cute art and sound design, but more and more I found myself being frustrated by unclear and unintuitive puzzle design. It feels like the most interesting puzzles are front-loaded, and from the third chapter onwards the game seems to favour complex and tedious sorting puzzles, which ended up being time-consuming instead of satisfying and novel like some of the earlier puzzles. As much as I love a good puzzle game, I ended up quitting out of this one in frustration. Puzzle design and difficulty can be a hard line to walk, but unfortunately this one falls on the wrong side of it for me.

Not what is advertised and what was shown in the demo.

Pretends to be a chill sorting game. Which it is, for the first third (and in the demo), but then things switch up and it becomes an annoying puzzler, which requires far too much precision (that is me with mild sorting OCD speaking, it is not about the precision, but about the game system not recoginising correct solutions if they are not EXACTLY and UTTERLY PRECISELY executed as the game demands) and it even has stressful bits, in which you quickly have to dissuade the cat (which was cute in the first third) from knocking things over or quickly stop a plant from regrowing leaves. The latter was the final straw for me and I dropped the game at this point. 

TL, DR: I tried to love it, but it left me wanting in terms of relaxation and sorting satisfaction and instead wanted me to play a sometimes time-based puzzler.

__________________________________________________________________________

Answer to the devs:

Sure, I figured that at least the plant puzzle was not truly time based (I really don't see how the cat bit wasn't, because you had to dissuade it from effing up your sorting again and again), but I was done with the line of unobvious puzzles, because that was not why I bought the game in the first place and not why I wanted to play it. 
Because, and the point remains standing, this game was advertised as a chill sorting game. Which. 
It. 
Is. 
Not. 
It is a puzzler primarily, because the sorting goes out the window after the first third, as I wrote.

Great that you work on the precision bit, I bet it will make a lot of other ppl happy!
However, again, that does not change the fact that this game is not what it seems and the demo did not show what the majority of the game would be.

So, I suggest you stop picking out the things I said that might not have been a 100% accurate and face the fact that you released a product that differs greatly from advertisement and demo. 
Puzzler =/= sorting game.
End of story.

This game could be so good, but it falls short. Some levels are intuitive enough that they make sense, but somewhere between "half" and "most" of the puzzles don't give any indication at all of what you're supposed to do. For example, one level gives you a handful of pencils of varying lengths. The natural assumption is that you are supposed to arrange them in order based on their length, which is true, but what the game gives you NO indication of AT ALL is that you're supposed to [spoiler]arrange them in very specific spots on the single-color background[/spoiler]. 

Another example is a level where it gives you a bunch of envelopes with some stamps. Again, with NO indication of what you're supposed to do, you have to just click around the guess, Turns out, you [spoiler]are supposed to make the stamps on the envelopes into patterns by placing the stamps[/spoiler]. 

Another level has you stack papers on top of each other, but then a very similar appearing level wants you arrange them on (invisible) hot spots around the background. There's nothing distinguishing those mechanics.

So this game is basically just "click around randomly until you find the invisible hot spots." It seems like they are supposed to be puzzles for you to figure out, but forgot to include the actual puzzle.

The "hint" system gives you the full answer (at least on the levels I used it on), which is definitely not a reasonable thing for a game like this that gives no indication of what you're supposed to do.

I don't generally bash on games where it's obvious I'm not the target audience, because I don't think that's really fair. In this case though, I *am* the target audience, as far as I can tell, and enjoyed the few levels that made sense.  2/10, A for effort. If the UI were fixed to provide indicators for where the invisible hot spots are, or even indicators about what each puzzle is supposed to be, maybe a riddle or something, the game could be so much better.

I wanted to love this game. Having enjoyed Unpacking and Assemble with Care, I thought this would run in a similar vein. Unfortunately A Little to the Left - while it looks great - quickly becomes annoying and frustrating. What the game wants from you as a solution is often obscure and you have to rely on the hint (which gives you the solution right away. A gradual hint system would have been much better). Not to mention how finicky placement can be. On a particular level involving tools, the game would not accept my solution because one item was a pixel or two out of alignment, despite being where the damn thing needed to be.

I came into the game with big expectations with the recent successes of similar cosy organisation games such as unboxing but unfortunately this fell flat for me.

There is little that is relaxing or zen with this game, it is essentially just a puzzle game. There is no forgiving nature in it such as unboxing where you could place items where you want within reason, this game is hard and fast with the positioning and the 'hints' either give the solution away entirely or are too obtuse.

I have had a lovely time playing this game. A little to the left is a great sit down and unwind game if you enjoy little puzzles. The art style is lovely, and the atmosphere makes it very sweet. 

The few complaints I have are mostly accessibility, while there is an option to leave a puzzle as is and move on, with potential to come back to the next one, and great hints in place, I found some of the puzzles to be difficult to decipher purely based on not enough contrast in the visuals. In some places i found that the push for aesthetic trumped the ability to see what the puzzle wanted, or even the pieces of the puzzle. 

(for those who have played, particularly the constellation based puzzles I found very difficult to discern what was a movable star and what wasn't, and found myself clicking aimlessly)

Otherwise, all in all i had a very positive experience with the game and love the style. If you enjoy a no pressure game, this is a great one to play.

A LOT of the puzzles require at least some colour vision. I had to use third party programs to distinguish the different colours in order to play the majority of it.

If they incorporate something that will help us colour vision deficient folks, then I would definitely change my review. But for now, I definitely wouldn't recommend it.

I love the idea of this game. The visuals are fantastic and cute, the cat messing with you is an adorable touch... BUT. The 'puzzles' that were advertised as a cute, organize-y zen game are sometimes obtuse and weirdly specific in their requirements. Maybe I am extra dumb, but its like the game is constantly saying stuff like, "NO I wanted you to order the pencils by size from THIS direction!; NO I wanted you to put these books in order by this little pattern band on the bottom, the fact that the random heights scattered everywhere is not irritating at all." For some puzzles I just found myself saying "I don't know what you want!" In the developers effort to create something 'satisfying,' they actually create something obtuse, specific, and 'incorrectly ordered' that grates on your sense of order and satisfaction like sandpaper. Plus the 'hint' button, is literally just the answer. I hate to break out this card but other people are too so I want to clear something up. As someone with actual OCD, this does not necessarily placate urges and it does not necessarily soothe the compulsions because everyone with a diagnosis is different and will fixate on different things. OCD IS NOT JUST ABOUT WANTING TO ORGANIZE STUFF ffs.

Such a relaxing game, I did have a tiny bit of trouble on some but I managed to get it just needed to relax more and maybe ask help from my hubby but other than that super recommend! I love the kitty.

I was hoping for something to tell a visual story like Unpacking...  And what I got was a very simple, hand-holdy "puzzle" game where you just move things around until they snap to a spot, and then keep trying different items in different snap-to spots until you hear a chime.  Repeat ad-nauseum.  Which is a shame, because the visuals are lovely and I LOVE knolling and organizing.  After the third "put these pencils in order" level I got bored enough to quit.

You also cannot re-map key bindings.  From what I played you likely won't have to use the keyboard, but there was one level that my mouse just couldn't get something to move far enough to snap-to and chime so I had to use WASD to complete the level.  I am not a WASD keymap player for accessibility reasons.  So this game is potentially not accessible to some players if they need to use the keyboard and don't or can't use WASD.

For the people that like when everything has its own place. 

This review comes after full "story" completion, and most solution variation completed for those interested in time to complete!

I can't say how much I appreciate that the game had little nudges towards the "correct" answer for the puzzles, and that there are *multiple* ways to complete the puzzles. Most of the levels are variations on a theme, and after completing simple versions early on, the later puzzles become less cryptic for what needs to be accomplished.

The aesthetics of the game were super satisfying to work within, and the hints work well within this little world the developers created. You can reveal only as much as you need while still needing to do a little leg work to determine what the hint is referring to.

I played bits of this on controller and keyboard, and both work great. The controller has lock on for certain puzzles where things get kinda small to grab. Things that require precision placement are also nudged into place where necessary, and certain objects will reorient themselves to give you a tiny hint of where they might need to be placed.

Overall, a quick little game to pick up that's peaceful with bits of humor! There's also "daily tidies" that you can come back to for little puzzles every day.
There were only two or three puzzles I had to use the hint for, but I hate being frustrated so relatively easy puzzles are a win for me.

You looked a trailer and this game seems fun, relaxing and meditating? Nope, it doesn't. I have check reviews before buying and have some misleading thoughts, but now I get it too. It's just another boring hard-coded sorting puzzle game, but with good marketing, nice graphics and "cute" cat.
First of all, this is not how "Full controller support" should work. Can you imagine mapping mouse cursor directly to controller joystick movement? Does this seems absurd to you? Well, developers saw this as a good idea and implemented it just like this.
"Puzzles" are rather boring and sometimes counter-intuitive. In first color crayons puzzle I sorted them in opposite direction and guess what? IT DOESN'T COUNT. After that and a few more puzzle I just realized that this game nor fun, nor relaxing. My whole experience and expectations for this game was ruined not because I'm too dum to sort this, but because I can't sort thing in a way I like.

This is the kind of game where I really wish there an option for a middle choice between "I recommend" and "I don't recommend." Basically my experience with this from puzzle to puzzle was all over the place. I'd say between 1/3 and 1/2 of the puzzles left me deeply frustrated for reasons I can't give other than "that's not how my brain works." I would run into puzzles where I flatly could not figure out what it wanted from me, and others where I did something that made total sense to me wasn't an acceptable solution (that second thing wouldn't bug me except for when I found out some puzzles have multiple accepted solutions and somehow what made 100% sense to me still wasn't among the solutions). When it frustrated me, it REALLY frustrated me. But the hint system got me through, and some of the puzzles were deeply satisfying to figure out on my own. So... I just slogged through the frustrations for the hit of joy when one fully clicked with me. So call it a tepid recommendation.

I was looking for a relaxing but satisfying game after Unboxing, and this looked very similar. You basically just click and drag objects until they are in some kind of "satisfying" order, like arranging books in height order.

The first few levels were easy, but satisfying. Then the game quickly devolved into really confusing levels where it's not clear at all what you're supposed to be doing. For example, there's a level with a calendar and a pack of stickers with flowers, dots, squiggles, etc. Some stickers have already been placed on the calendar, so you need to figure out which days you should put the rest of them on. After a while of not being able to figure it out, I went to the forum, and someone said that you just have to put a sticker every 9 days. Why? I don't understand. What appointment does anyone have that is every 9 days?? How is the player meant to figure that out???

After a few of these puzzles I was becoming genuinely irritated. I don't mind paying a lot for a niche indie experience but I'm probably just going to refund this one.

:3c

I really wanted to like this game. 
It was sold to me as a really satisfying and zen game about organising things. A part of it is, and those parts are fantastic. The art is simple and cute. It has all the right parts to make it a great game. 

But it isn't. 

To much of the game is increasingly difficult and obscure solutions to, what should be, simple puzzles. 
Do the developers expect me to sit on those leaf levels (especially the second one) and trial and error the solution? Without giving to much away for people that do what to try this game. This "puzzle" involves selecting the right items out of everything or it resets. Normal games have visual indicators or patters to assist this. This game said no to that. 
Why are those blank screen and random item "puzzles" like that? I thought it might just be like a timed thing where you can move on after playing with the items for a certain amount of time, or that there was some sort of picture to build. No. There is a picture to build...a hyper specific picture...with no reference to it...and everything has to be specifically placed or you won't get the level. 
Honestly, I never thought a game about organising would need a walk-through, but this game does. It is also super sad to see the walk-through's with explanations for the solutions to the "puzzles" being "I have no idea why this is the solution, it just is." 
I think that is the problem. The "puzzles"exist to stump you and be different. Not to scratch the itch that organising brings. 

The game does have hints though....and by hints....I mean they give you the answer. I'm assuming because even they know that some solutions are too stupid and complex for anyone to spend time figuring out. 

To be honest, I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone that wants to have a relaxing time. There are better games out there.

A wonderful scratch to the deepest folds of my brain. I'm colorblind so some puzzles were rough. Got some friends to help me and we had a blast. 10/10 would recommend.

this game is very charming. the art style, the music and the concepts are all unique and very well done.

I find this game super enjoyable! Great time killer and head-scratcher. If you are a fan of puzzles, you will get lots of enjoyment out of this. I really like that some of them have multiple solutions. Whenever I finish a new one I feel compelled to go back and find the other possibilities. I do wish the hints were not outright solutions, but I appreciate the eraser so that you can reveal as much or as little of the solution as you'd like. Overall, great game and I look forward to future updates!
A good game. I beat it in one day :)

It's a great puzzle game and works your brain just enough to relieve stress. I especially loved the levels where you get to organize items into toolboxes, silverware drawers, etc. It's super relaxing. However, some of the levels are pretty confusing and need a little guidance.

the game is super cute and i love the art style, but i don't think its worth the full Â£12.99. definitely worth the play if it's on sale though! the game is rather short and once you've completed everything there's not much else you can do apart from the daily tidy - and these are just variations of levels from the main game with no real incentive to do them. i did enjoy playing though and i'm still trying to get all the stars and achievements, it's just the price that bothers me.
Amazing game, I would have given it a 10/10...... but you get to pet the cat so 13/10

I loved the demo and was so pumped to play it once it came out! All the levels are really fun to play, a range of difficulties. Some took me a long time to solve all the way through which I love. I was really excited when I saw the daily challenges but pretty disappointed when they were just repeats of other levels, and on top of that, sometimes its the same one twice in a row. I wish there was some extras thrown in there at least once in a while. Also they're all the easiest levels to solve, no real challenges on the daily challenges which was also disappointing. I will say though that the look of the game is super aesthetically pleasing, same with the sound effects. I can tell a lot of effort was put into that aspect for sure. Overall a fun game the first time through but a little disappointing after that.

I have played the game for a bit now, and the lack of any communication on what is expected for the "puzzle" and the fact that hint is just an answer, really makes the game not enjoyable. Fighting myself to figure out how someone wants something organized, without looking at the answer out of defeat instead of some context clues, is a waste of my money and time. 

(Original review: The puzzles dont tell you whats expected, not a slight just an annoyance at times. There are hints but it makes me feel defeated to use them! Love the cat paw its usually unexpected.)

Super cute and relaxing "puzzle" game, where you sort and origanise things in just the right way.

I played the demo and was excited for this to come out, but honestly, pay attention to the negative reviews. Although the art and music is lovely, and some of the levels are good, overall it was a disappointment. I found the puzzles either too simple or too abstract, and in only a couple of hours they began to get repetitive and frustrating. 

This was recommended to me because of "Unpacking" but I wouldn't say this game is for people who like to organize homes/shelves/etc. in that way. I found myself getting stressed and annoyed because I was being asked to sort abstract things in random ways that really had nothing to do with tidying a home -- the object flatlays (shells, autumn foliage, etc.) were the worst offenders. Having played the demo, I was expecting more desk drawer sorting, not "put together a microscopic snowflake." This is much more of a puzzle game (but I could see puzzle fans getting frustrated since it feels like the game has too little variety, unbalanced challenge levels, sometimes completely random solutions, and isn't really satisfying). 

If you're a casual puzzle fan (like super casual), maybe this could work for you, but I'd still recommend waiting until it goes on sale.

TLDR - Get it on sale.

Really cute game. I was excited when I saw someone play it on YouTube and thought I had to get it. And it was super relaxing and calming. The music was charming. But it was really short. I even went back through and got some of the stars I missed the first time around. I'd say if the game is on sale, definitely worth it, but $15 is a lot to ask for how short it was and the "daily" rounds don't really make me want to open it every day just for 5 minutes, if that.
I was diagnosed with OCD years ago and this game makes me feel valid in wanting everything perfect. I love the different puzzles, such a good game.

It's not a bad puzzle game. But the emphasis should be on PUZZLE. Due to the marketing I was expecting a more zen experience like unboxing. So much of the game offers itself as "organizing, with multiple solutions for puzzles, and sometimes a cute cat to fuss with". My experience was more "increasingly obtuse puzzles meant to stump you on purpose, and a cat that appears largely once you've beaten your head against a puzzle and solved it just to mess it up on purpose". It's a cute game, I don't entirely regret getting it. But it was NOT remotely what I had wanted going into it. Which is a shame, since the first few puzzles hit that satisfying spot. But it soon turned to 'there is one RIGHT way to do this' solutions, and I found myself struggling to interpret what the creator thought was a "satisfying" solution versus what I thought looked appealing. By the last chapter, all the stages are metaphysical challenges (spoilers : one has you moving a mirror to arrange items specifically how they appear in the reflection, in order to match) with hard "there is One Right Way to solve this" answers. I hadn't bought this looking for a game that was "oops all adventure room point and click game puzzles". I wanted something more like Unpacking that perhaps had solutions but freeform and relaxing enough to not feel like I was fighting the game just to finish it.

Also, that tupperware end scene went on for WAY too long.

*I DO NOT HATE THE GAME*
It's a very cute game that I was very much looking forward to, however to my surprise, I actually am not a huge fan of this game. I can definitely see the appeal, however I found it very hard to play this game without referencing a walkthrough for a majority of the levels. There are many levels where you rearrange the items to fit the screen nicely, and while they were satisfying, there was only one correct answer. I found myself arranging it on the screen nicely and then it wouldn't complete the level, just to go check the walkthrough and see that I did it completely wrong. Could be a skill issue lol, but I did not find this as relaxing as I had hoped. Definitely a thinker.
Such a lovely relaxing game :)

Beautifully designed organisation game that doesn't stray too far into the obscure. 

I've played point-and-clicks before, and I don't tend to get along with them, often finding the puzzle solutions too obscure. You're expected to read the developers mind - this isn't the case with A Little to the Left, because I know it was made by people whose brains work the same way as mine. 

It took a little getting used to, learning what is and isn't an acceptable approach to organisation within the game's world, but once you've learned it, you'll probably be able to power through the game and return to the puzzles that didn't click on another day (thank you for the 'let it be' feature)! I only needed to look up the solutions to the most obscure puzzles, but probably could have sussed them if I'd given myself enough time. The daily tidy is also neat, though quickly becomes repetitive.

As an aside, the art and sound design are brilliant. Well worth the purchase.

I really like the relaxing nature of the game. The entire game is super cute and has great music that goes perfectly with the idea behind the game. I'm bummed that it wasn't a bit longer but the ending made up for it. All in all, its a chill game that's well worth it.
An absolutely beautiful game.  10/10 would stack containers again.
Such a feel good game. Very relaxing and stimulating. My only complaint is I want more!

I love love this game!! It's so calming & easy to complete each level. Some of them did make me have to ask for a small hint, but not all of them, which is really nice. I just wish there were more levels; I got through them all T__T
Such a fun and relaxing puzzle game! It's my favorite game to play when I need to relax.
Its such an aesthetic and comforting game.

What a fun puzzle game! Though it's not very long, I found it very satisfying to play. The art style and music give it a relaxing vibe that I really enjoyed and I really appreciated that the game allows you to solve many of the puzzles in multiple ways. It's so nice to see a game recognize that there's more than one way to complete these kind of things!

The antics of the cat and the nature of many of the puzzles had me chuckling and sometimes turning my screen to share with my spouse, which is always a great sign. When someone else in the room (who isn't playing the game) can appreciate a joke or a nice piece of artwork/music, you're doing something right! My husband even turned off his own game music and asked me to make Little Too The Left louder because he was enjoying the soundtrack.

I think the only complaint I could possibly have would be that I want more, but really--that's hardly a complaint at all.

But after my 4.6 hours of play time, I have essentially completed the game. They have "Daily Tidys" to add replay value, but from what I've seen so far, they are just re-skins of existing levels. 

I really wanted more levels where you organize a large number of items like the junk drawer level. I hope the developer plans to add more content to this series over time, or additional DLCS. I might be willing to purchase those. But for now, I have to say "Not Recommended." There simply isn't enough content!

This game is so adorable and satisfying. From the colors, the clicks, the music, the little bits and pieces of story telling.. this game is nothing but wonderful and sweet and fun to play! Highly recommend for anyone who needs a little help in their day to unwind and work their brain gears a bit!

All in all, "A Little to the Left" is a very enjoyable and satisfying experience - even if a few of the puzzles are not quiet as intuitive as probably intended (the hint mechanic will save you in those rare occasions). Lovely art style and animations, wonderful soundtrack, lots of achievements. Perhaps a bit pricy? Nevertheless, I do recommend!

A cute concept, but not all that well executed - for the asking price I would've expected a much more cohesive experience that allowed for different expressions when choosing how to solve each level.

Was fun

Reasons I loved this game:
1. Diversity of puzzles and the ability to solve certain puzzles in multiple ways really keeps your mind intrigued. I really love that it forces you to think of the puzzle in different perspectives ( shapes, numbers, colours, etc.) 
2. Cuteness factor! The little storyline with the kitty is absolutely adorable and really shows the "joys" of owning a cat. Reminiscent of the Cats organized neatly and dogs organized neatly game. 
3. I did think the let it be and hint options were nice additions. I wish the hint button didn't give you the full answer tho. 
4. End credits.... I won't spoil it but the change of perspective is hilarious! 
5. This game really brought me back to some of the puzzle games/tv of my childhood like Cyberchase, I Spy (Books and PC games), Crashbox, etc. The nostalgia really hit hard and left me with a lot of happiness.
A great little puzzle game that's theme of organization is aided by clean and simple artwork. Very fun but once the main puzzles are completed I find it challenging to go back for the daily ones.

This has to be the most satisfying game I have ever played! No pressure, relaxing music, organising things to be just right, and a surprising amount of replay ability. You can get through the whole game relatively fast but some of the extra stars are hard to get right away. I love the Daily Tidy as well, makes me want to come back everyday to see what puzzle is showcased. 10/10
Fun game but I finished it within 3 hours. Very calming but is not worth $15.
A good, fun, relaxing game

I highly recommend this game for those who just need to relax far a bit. I happened to finish this game in about 3 hours, but there is a built in "daily tidy" that you can do once a day. Overall, amazing game with an equally amazing art style!
If you enjoy calming puzzle games, this is the perfect game for you! The puzzles were challenging but not frustrating and the music/sounds scratched my brain in such a good way.

There are so many things I enjoyed about this game.  The art style, the amount of levels, the music, the environmental storytelling.... It was so fantastic to play.  I thoroughly enjoyed this game so much.

One of  my favourite features of this game was the "Let It Be" feature.  The way it was worded and the fact that I could.... let a puzzle be as it was and move on was so nice.  I really enjoy puzzle games, but sometimes I really struggle solving them and with the frustration I would stop playing.  This feature allowed me to continue without feeling bad for continuing to another level.

I thought, for me, the difficulty levels were pretty well balanced for me.  I am very much a novice puzzle enjoyer, so I found some puzzles challenging enough, and some more easy and I enjoy that a lot.

This game was such a joy to play, and I am honestly so excited to go back and play through the whole thing again!
fantastic puzzle organizer i love it!!!!

Such a fun game. The puzzles are really innovative and a lot of them I had to work with my partner to figure out. Because there is a slight random aspect ot many of them there is replay value as well + the daily tidy.
very good.

Sweet little game that doesn't prove too taxing. Although, sometimes it is not clear what you are meant to do.
This game plays so well with my perfectionist mind, there are enough levels for me to not finish it in a day AND even if i did finish it fast there are daily tasks! I loved playing through them all
Very chill. Not too challenging, but enough to let you feel like you've done something

This is a really fun game, if you like relaxing puzzles. I really like how there are some levels that have multiple solutions, and that the levels are unique. You also get more than just the levels as they have a daily challenge, they can take a few seconds or you struggle with them until you get the "ohhhh" moment.

I personally think you should wait for a sale to buy this, but you'll still get a ton of fun out of it.

9/10
very satisfying, i wish there were more levels where you just put stuff in a drawer

I wish I had read through reviews more before buying this game.  It looked really cute and like it could be a fun but casual puzzle game, but the mechanics are not intuitive.  There are a number of levels that have no visual clues or guidance as to what you're supposed to be doing.  There are other levels where you think you can just sort items into an aesthetically pleasing design (nature levels) and dozens of ways you could do it with the space you're given.  But no there's a very very specific way to solve the level and the game will not accept anything else.  The only way to know is to go to the level's hint through the menu.  I'm really not a fan of having to "cheat" in order to get through levels just because I can't figure out what the game is trying to get me to do.  

A few other reviews pointed out that items will snap to a grid but they don't really do that.  The hit box for it must be really small or just not sensitive enough. I found I was putting things in the same spot with nothing happening unit the 10th time I put it there or placed another object near it to kind of push it in.  

This was supposed to be relaxing and I'm honestly way more stressed out than I would be playing most other games.  I would not recommend this to anyone, and I can't see myself playing this again, which is a shame considering how much it cost.  I just wanted a casual and calming game to play, but I feel like I've wasted 2 hours and money just to feel tense.
Jumpscared by cat
a fun little tidy-up game that scratches the itch in your brain perfectly. also it has a cat.

A little to the Left is beautifully illustrated puzzle game that will get the gears turning in your head. With that being said I feel it is a little pricey of a game.  I would definitely wait and pick it up on sale.

Pros:
- thought provoking puzzle
- Select puzzles have multiple solutions
- Visually stunning
- There are daily puzzles, but keep in mind they will be similar to puzzles you have already completed

Cons:
- Price point is a little to high
Very satisfying gameplay with lots of unique mechanics.

[i]This Game Actively Gave my Brain Anxiety[/i]

I wanted to like this game. I did. And I tried. I [i]love[/i] puzzle games, and this was pitched to me as a ""relaxing"" puzzle/organisational game. 

It's not relaxing. It's really, really not relaxing. In fact, it's frustrating. So frustrating in fact that I could feel my brain splitting in half as I desperately tried to figure out what the game wanted me to do on some stages. [spoiler] "Oh, the spoons have to go in the little section with ever so slightly rounded corners? oh NEATOâ€”" [/spoiler]

So, perhaps I went into it with the wrong expectations, thus ruining it for myself forever. Maybe it won't be the same for you.

However, I feel like even if I had been told, "hey, this is a puzzle game," I'd still feel a bit irked. The cursor feels janky/rigid no matter how I change the settings (and no other games are giving me this trouble). The cat in this game, somehow, is the first cat in a video game that [i]I feel myself hating.[/i] It's not enjoyable seeing hard work get destroyed by its malicious l'il paws.

Things came to a crashing end for me at the Box level. I don't know what happened to me. It was like my brain was actually getting tortured. Neurons were screaming at me that they didn't get it. Click, Grab, Click, Grab, Shuffle, Click, Grab, [i]it can't go there[/i], Click, Grab, Click, Grab, Shuffleâ€” 

This game is going to be satisfying for some people. I know it will be. But, there is a small chance, a tiny chance, that maybe your brain is like mine and that this game is serotonin [i]poison[/i] that you just paid $22.95AUD to make your brain scream at you.

Doing the bare minimum in A Little to the Left is the fun, relaxing organizing experience it makes itself out to be. Trying to 100% it, on the other hand, is sometimes like staring at one of those stereoscopic images where it looks like a bunch of TV static but it promises, allegedly, that if you look at it in juuuust the right way it'll become a bunny. I mean this in the best possible way.

A Little to the Left has the amount of thought put into its concept (reflected in the multiple modalities of solving, the environmental story, and a well-crafted artsy aesthetic) that puts it beyond merely a novelty or oddity based in its particular appeal. It could have skirted by on its unique concept alone, but it didnâ€™t â€“ and for a game based on an observant, details-orientated mindset, it shows.

I can't wait to see what else Max Inferno comes out with next, but this gives a hopeful outlook on what's to come.

This game is so satisfying! I played the demo a while back and was looking forward to the full release. So glad it's finally here. There are occasional puzzles that seem a bit convoluted. One or two I didn't understand even after using the "hint" mechanic to solve it. Most are pretty intuitive to solve without a hint, or by just uncovering one tiny portion of the hint screen to give you a place to start. 
I also like how there are visual and auditory clues when you get something right or wrong. Things snap into place and a tiny chime sounds when you get it right, for many puzzles. (Things can also snap or settle into the wrong place, but it doesn't chime in this case.) If something is in the wrong spot, it will often skew off-kilter so you  know it doesn't go there. 
Overall, I find this puzzle game to be calming and very enjoyable and I look forward to continuing. I am about to finish chapter 3 after just shy of 4 hours, and have unlocked 10/51 achievements. I am not specifically seeking achievements yet, but likely will go back for any I missed. I noticed you can go back and replay previous puzzles which I was grateful for because I accidentally skipped one I was having a tough time with, when I was trying to figure out if I had to save. (Note: the game seems to auto-save your progress.) 
Daily puzzles are a total mystery to me. Have not been able to solve one.
*edited to correct the time played*
Second edit: About 8.5 hours to get all solutions to all puzzles. Thank you to the reviewer who mentioned the "stars" as I hadn't even noticed them. I thought it was pretty fun to go back and think of another way to solve the same puzzle besides the first way that occurred to me. Overall I enjoyed this game a lot, and I'll probably go back to do the Daily Tidy occasionally as well.

[h1] A Little to the Left [/h1]
[b] 5/5 â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜… [/b]
  
[b] This game is a great example of superb game design. [/b]
[u] A Little to the Left [/u] really takes advantage of the feeling of satisfaction you get from using your intuition and being right. It is such a good feeling, and one that you will get often as you figure out each puzzle's clever solution(s).
Chapters are organized with their own themes, which helps making them feel distinct and resonate with a broader range of players through their own life experiences.

The artistic direction is impeccable, both through the game's minimalist and clean visuals, as well as through its very cozy soundtrack, both of which bring out emotions and meaning throughout the playthrough.

The difficulty of the puzzles does not get in the way of enjoyment or progression, as the player always has the option to "Let it be", i.e. to leave the puzzle as it is and go to the next one. However, the fact that some puzzles have multiple solutions, some harder than others, as well as "secret" solutions in the form of achievements, proves truly useful in making the experience last a little bit longer.

If I had to criticize one thing, it would be the multiple steam Achievements that are either not unlocking properly and/or unobtainable at realease, but I noticed some changes have already been made in that regard, and hopefully all achievements will work as intended soon.

[u] A Little to the Left [/u] is a genuinely good game, and one that I would strongly recommend to anyone looking for a casual, wholesome, and satisfying experience. 

P.S. the end credits were successful in making me and several other players on streams feel emotional, and this speaks volumes about the design choices and the genuine part of themselves that the developers put into the game through this very humanizing moment.

I wanted to love this game and in theory it was perfect, but it has so many issues that make it unenjoyable. For starters, I personally find the music and sound effects to have a lot of sudden high tones which are not relaxing in the slightest. But that's easily solved, just kind of defeats the purpose a little bit.

[h1] Controls [/h1]
The controls are god awful. My resolution is set correctly yet it makes me play with a giant cursor and some of the puzzles were resulting in my mouse going off screen and my movement snapped back to what it was before. I tried playing with a controller and it was the most frustrating experience ever, there are too many things to move around from and it's too clunky.

[h1] Puzzles[/h1]
The puzzles were cute and I liked the idea, but in a game where some of them have multiple solutions, why not ask us if we want to try again for the other solutions? That just didn't make any sense to me and the menus feel so clunky that going back to do that is a pain. Also some of the solutions are just weird depending on how your brain works. There's one set with some books and they're SUPPOSED to start with ONE big one, the smallest going in the middle, and back up to a big one. I personally did it in decreasing size order because that's how I'd personally want to organize something like that. And playing on a controller and having to move all those books around? No. I personally feel like a game about moving things to organize them should give you a little bit more freedom, or I guess have more solutions stored. Everyone arranges things differently and being stuck in a box with this makes it quite annoying. Even Unpacking has a mode that you can freely place things and while that wouldn't translate exactly here, I think having one solution for most of those puzzles is a mistake and makes it less appealing to people who obsess over organization.

Let's not beat around the bush, this game specifically appeals to people with various mental illnesses and the way they set it up doesn't work well with those mental illnesses. I'm sure for some people this is great but if you have issues letting go of control or need things to be a certain way? Pass on this.

I absolutely love this game. It is very intuitive to control but as you play the puzzles get increasingly more challenging.
